October 10, 1923

Honorable D. C. Scott,
Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa.

Honorable Sir;

We are very grateful to you, Honorable Sir, for according us the amount of Five hundred dollars ($500.00), for part of Kitchen equipment for the St. Albert Boarding School, but greatly regret that the full estimation given for same was not received.

However, Honorable Sir, we rely upon your generosity and kindness for the future, in regard to this favor, as it is almost impossible for us to finance such a necessary purchase, out of per capita earnings.

Thanking you for past favors,

Trusting to receive a favorable answer from you,

I have the honor to be,

Your obedient servant,

Sister [Signature]
Per Sec.
Ottawa, October 17, 1923.

Reverend Sister:

I am directed to acknowledge your letter of the 10th instant, referring to the grant for kitchen equipment for the St. Albert Indian Residential School.

As Mr. Indian Agent Race was instructed, under cover of the 26th ultimo, the Department can give favourable consideration to requests for this type of equipment, not exceeding $500. You should communicate with our representative and indicate what articles to this value you would like the Department to purchase.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. Sister Gosselin,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
St. Albert, Alta.
Sir,

having reference to your letter No. 110-1-5, dated 26th ultimo, in the matter of the purchase of kitchen equipment for the St. Albert Boarding School, I beg to advise that on reference to the Sister Superior I am informed that the following articles are the most useful and more badly needed, viz.,—

| Item                                      | Quantity | Description          | Price   |
|-------------------------------------------|----------|----------------------|---------|
| 1 - 50 gal. Cast Iron Steam Jacketed Kettle | Gurney   | $125.00              |
| 1 - 3 bushel Cast Iron Steam Cooker       |          | 4 baskets, Gurney    | $167.25 |
| 1 - 1000 lb. cap. Beatrice Cream Separator|          |                      | $152.75 |
| 1 - 13 in. hand-power potato peeler, Gurney |          |                      | $86.00  |

Total: $531.00

While the aggregate of the four articles mentioned, is $31.00 in excess of the amount allowed by the Department, I trust that the matter will be given favourable consideration as the articles are badly needed.

If authority is given for the purchase of these articles, please advise me whether they are to be purchased by me here, and at the price quoted, which is the lowest tender I have had on the articles named.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, Oct. 26, 1923.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 19th instant, with reference to kitchen equipment for the St. Albert Indian Residential School.

You may inform the Principal that the Department will call for prices for the four articles needed, and will make the purchase. The successful tenderers will be asked to send their accounts in duplicate to you, for certification.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Geo. H. Race, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Edmonton, Alta.

This direction

Sir,

The Reverend Principal of the St. Albert School has sent me an estimate of a playground for the girl pupils of that school which she has requested me to forward to Ottawa which I now do.

I am also informed by the Principal that on the occasion of a visit of the Mother Provincial at Ottawa the matter of this playground was taken up with the Department and she was advised to get an estimate made of the cost by a competent man and submit it to the Department.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

MONTREAL, November 7, 1923.

Purchasing Agent,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

We are enclosing herewith tender form, completed, which calls for One 50 Gallon Cast Iron Steam Jacketed Kettle, One Three Bushel Cast Iron Steam Cooker with four baskets, and One 12" Hand Power Potato Peeler.

The last item, we wish to particularly draw your attention to the fact that this is an American machine and is called the "Sterling" 13" Peeler. We are quoting on a "Cyclone" Vegetable Peeling Machine, a #8 Size which is 15" in diameter, and "Made in Canada," being essentially a Canadian product throughout and has been manufactured by us for the past sixteen years; in use by the leading institutions throughout Canada where we have replaced American made machines, notably Canadian Pacific Steamships Limited who are using our machines both on the Pacific and Atlantic Ocean, we recently sold them five more machines for their new boats.

The Department of Militia & Defence in 1918 ordered nearly 500 of these machines on the strength of a report by a Commission headed by the late Col. Hallick who tested out five different makes and he selected ours as being the best from every point.

We are enlarging on this particular item for the reason that we are under the impression that you are not aware that there is a Canadian machine which will do all that any American machine can claim, and more.

Trusting you will give this due consideration and hoping that our quotation meets with your favour, we remain

Very truly yours,

LEB/SCC.
JOHN BURNS & COMPANY

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter of Feb., 27th and supplementing ours of March 5th, we are pleased to send you herewith leaflet describing the type of motor on tripod stand, and pulley for separator, which will convey to you the idea which we had in mind of operating your Renfrew Cream Separator by electric motor. This outfit complete consists of ½ H.P. motor with stand and cord and pulley for separator and can be furnished for $79.50 complete.

We note that it was your intention that the separator ordered be electrically driven. However this does not appear to have been referred to in any of your correspondence leading up to the sale. We regret exceedingly that you did not order the type of machine you now appear to want, but if you still desire a self-contained, electrically driven separator same as illustrated on the cover of instruction book which we are sending you in preference to the apparatus detailed on the illustrated leaflet, we will exchange machines for you at an additional cost of $75.00 providing you will undertake to pay transportation charges.

The electrically driven machine is originally $65.00 higher priced than the hand-power machine and as you will understand a machine that has been in use even for a short time is considerably depreciated and would cost quite a lot to restore it to its original new condition, therefore in quoting you a price of $75.00 it is only $10.00 in excess of what you would have paid for the size 10 electric machine in the first place and this as we understand it, is what you require.

Will you kindly give the matter your consideration and tell us which of the above propositions will suit you best. If you would desire to have the new size 10 electric separator, let us know and we will ship it along to you at once and on its arrival you can return the machine you now have.

Will you please be sure and ascertain the correct power you have. In one of your former letters you refer to this as 160 volts and later it has been referred to as 110 to 120 volts. It is quite important that we have this correct so as to furnish suitable motor.

Awaiting your reply, we are,

Yours very truly

Honorable Sir;

Received your letter of the 7th Inst., in regard to the pavilions for our Indian pupils. As you have been so kind as to ask us to let you have an expression of our wishes in this connection, we beg you to kindly let the pavilions be built in the dimensions that we are now forwarding you, namely, 24 X 40.... No doubt for the present, the pupilage is only 100, but we hope in the near future, that the St. Albert Boarding School will be filled up with Indians as is, and has always been our desire... Then we will not have to go back again on these erections for enlargement. However, Honorable Sir, we do not want in any manner to go against your wishes;... In regard to these pavilions, each one will be erected on each of their respective playgrounds; one for the boys, and one for the girls, and will be for the pupils of our Indian school only.... Trusting to receive a favorable answer from you in regard to these pavilions that are really necessary for the comfort of our pupils.

I have the honor to be,

Your humble servant,

Sister Guerin.
Ottawa, June 23, 1924.

Dear Mr. Graham:

With further reference to your No. 403-11A of the 26th ultimo, regarding the two dining and recreation pavilions to be erected at the St. Albert Indian Residential School, I have to inform you that a communication has been received from the Rev. Sister Superior containing an expression of her wishes in this connection. She requests that the dimensions of each be 24 by 40 ft., one to be erected on the boys' and the other on the girls' playground. As you were advised, $4,000 has been provided for this purpose and for putting up proper fencing around the outside.

I shall be pleased if you will comply, in so far as the funds provided will permit, with the Rev. Sister's wishes regarding the size and other particulars in the erection of these pavilions. The principal states that they will be for the use of the Indian pupils only.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,

27th May 1927

Sir,

I beg to report that the present laundry at the St. Albert Boarding School is not at all what it should be. On my last visit I looked it over and found that it is in connection with the engine room and thoroughfare to the engine room. In the laundry is much machinery which although protected by iron rails is not sufficient for safety.

It does not appear to me that there is adequate room for the work which is carried on there apart from the undesirable fact that the engineers and other workmen have to pass forwards and backwards when going to or coming from the engine room when the girls are at work in the laundry.

On the west side of the building there is a space on which a laundry could be built and attached to the engine room.

The building required would be of brick like the main building with 3 walls and skylight roof. The size 53x24x10 ft, wall. This building fitted with the old equipment would cost about $6000 but if new revolving driers and mangles—which are badly needed—were installed it would cost about $8000 to $10000.

I may also remark that the present pumping system for the septic tank is not what it should be and if a new pumping arrangements are established, they would take up the space now used by the present laundry and which is the only place for the machinery to be.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of March 15th, in regard to the $4000.00 grant, suggested by the Deputy Superintendent General, Dr. Scott, as a part payment on the erection of our new laundry, I am enclosing a list of the equipment needed for the said laundry, also prices quoted on by the different firms, together with the cost of the fireproof building. Moreover you saw at the same time what expenses we are undergoing in regard to the new sewerage disposal plant we were having built anew compulsory by the Provincial Government, at a cost of $7,000.00. The total cost of the old and new sewerage disposal plants in the last seven years amounted to $14,000.00. Furthermore, we had to have a new installation of batteries which cost us the sum of $2,000.00.

By the above figures you can plainly see, that we have tried to do our utmost toward the upkeep of the school in every manner.

If the department could at least furnish $3,000.00 on the erection of the new said laundry, we would be most grateful, as at the present we have all we can do to make both ends meet, in regard to our daily expenses, interests, etc. Asking you kindly to take this matter up with the Deputy Superintendent General, Dr. Scott, hoping he will do his utmost for us, toward the furnishing of the $3,000.00 mentioned above.

And oblige

Dear Sir:

At your request, we are forwarding you the plan of our new laundry together with cost of machinery. As you will notice, a garage is attached to back of laundry. This garage being greatly needed, we thought it would be most convenient to have it built on to the end of laundry, as this was the site most satisfactory, needing only two walls to complete same. Mr. J.R. Desrochers of Edmonton, the man who made out the plan, estimates the garage at about $400.00, that is, all fire-proof. It is not our intention, that the Department shall pay for this garage, although we keep the care solely, for the accommodation of recruiting pupils on the different reserves. However, kind Sir, we shall greatly appreciate anything you can do for us, in regard to the building up of this said laundry and garage; and moreover, rely upon your generosity to do all in your power to have the full amount paid by the Dept. of Indian Affairs. We permit ourselves to speak to you in this manner, as you are about the only one, who knows clearly and exactly how we are standing in regard to our financial affairs.

Trusting you will do your utmost, to grant us this favor as generously as you have granted us, so many numerous others, and hoping to be able to say in future years, that the modern laundry and garage of the St. Albert Boarding School, was built up, equipped and paid for, by the Department of Indian Affairs, through the kindness and generosity of our Indian Commissioner, Mr. W. M. Graham, whose powerful words spoke up for us.

I have the honor to be,

Your humble servant,

ST. ALBERT R.C. INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

The school building is a very fine structure. It is bright, has high ceilings, and is well ventilated. I found it very clean and tidy throughout. It is well equipped with facilities for fighting fire, and there is easy access to the fire escapes.

Since my last visit a laundry has been added to the main building. This is 42'x27' with a 19'6" ceiling. Access to this is obtained through a porch leading to the main building. This makes it unnecessary for the children to enter the engine room. The building, unequipped, has cost $6,040.00. The estimated cost of machinery and equipment was given to me as $6,000.00, which will bring the total cost to over $12,000.00. This is a very good building. It has a cement floor, and a pedestal 7 ft. high has been provided for a motor so that it will be well out of reach of the children. The Sisters are looking forward with considerable anxiety to having the Department bear a share of the cost of this laundry. They hope that the Department will bear 50% of the expense. I was present when they gave their estimate of cost to Dr. Scott two years ago, and they then stated that they expected the cost would be around $8,000.00. They have exceeded this estimate by a third more. The Sisters stated that they recently had to expend $12,000.00 in installing a septic tank and drainage to comply with the provincial regulations, and they found the additional cost of the laundry a heavy burden on them. They have not had a great deal of assistance at this institution in the past, and it appears to me that they are deserving of some consideration by the Department.

They have
They have, at the present time, a very capable staff. The three Sisters in charge of the classrooms are reported on as being quite capable teachers by the Provincial School Inspector, and the percentage of marks obtained by the pupils on his test appears to be quite satisfactory.

A large farm is operated in connection with this school. The work on the farm is largely done with hired help. They have 144 cattle and were milking 32 cows at the time of my visit. They have an ample supply of milk and butter for their own use. They raise hogs and have a large flock of poultry, so that the stock and poultry provide an important source of food supply. The boys assist in the care of the stock, under supervision, and do the milking. The girls are taught to make butter and bread, and, in fact, they are given a training in general domestic work. They have a large garden, which supplied ample potatoes and vegetables last season for their requirements.

I may say that the clothing for the children is all made at the school by the pupils.

The foregoing report is respectfully submitted.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

W. Morrison,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Honorable Sir:

Knowing you understand our financial point of standing, and how tremendously hard it is for us to make both ends meet, here we are again, taking up your time to listen to our tales of woe.

In our laundry we have one of our large tubs that is completely worn out to the last thread; as this costs money to have another installed, and we, not having the means to do so, owing to such hard times, decided to place our case before our good Doctor Scott, who in the past has been so generous towards our school in every manner.

Another case hanging on our shoulders is, that owing to last year's fire, that we had in the school, and almost certain that the indian pupils were the culprits, we were compelled to hire a night watchman, for the sake of the lives of so many children in the building; this no doubt, you understand is an extra expense to us. As we have but very few white children in the school owing to the hard times, and quite a number of indian children, and they being the treacherous ones, do you think, Honorable Sir, that the Department could help us out in paying the salary of the night watchman, together with a night watchman's clock; this clock being an absolute necessity, as he would have to punch it each time that he would visit around the different departments and in this manner we would know if he remains on duty or not.

If all the above items were not an absolute necessity and we really had the means to meet the expense, we would not hesitate to go right ahead and not bother you, but we cannot see our way through as we stand today, and having the above problems weighing us down, makes it very miserable for us.

Pegging you, Honorable Sir, to do your utmost to give us a helping hand as you have always done in the past.

I have the honor to be, Honorable Sir,

Your humble servant,

Sister M.A. Surprenant, Principal.

Permit me, Honorable Sir, to draw your attention to the interview that I had with you in your recent visit to our school regarding our wash-tub. I dread placing this item again before your eyes, but I am positive, that you fully understand our situation and moreover our financial difficulties. As it is impossible to undertake any more washings with this machine, and we, seeing fully that we have not the means to have it replaced, may I be permitted, Honorable Sir, to ask you to take this matter into consideration with the Department, and do your utmost to have them give us a helping hand.

Sir:

The Department is in receipt of a letter from the Principal of the St. Albert Residential School, with reference to the washtub. The Sister Superior requests that a new one be provided.

Please interview the Principal, ascertain exactly what she requires and advise the Department, stating what expenditure would be involved.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 15th instant, and in reply beg to report that I have interviewed the Rev. Sister Superior of the St. Albert Residential School and beg to advise the Department that she requires a medium size washtub, these are made by the Canadian Laundry Machinery Company, Ltd., Toronto, Ont.

The Rev. Sister Superior has asked for a double compartment washtub, and the approximate cost would be $650.00. I wish to state that the motor is in good condition and that only the washtub would be required, and could be set up by their own engineer. In the event of the Department supplying this washtub will you please have it shipped direct to St. Albert on the C.N.Railway.

I am Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

During his trip this summer, the Deputy Superintendent General visited the St. Albert Residential School and his attention was drawn to the necessity for supplying what the Sisters called a "wash tub".

Ottawa, March 21, 1935.

Sir:

For some time past, the Department has been allowing a grant at the rate of $40 a month towards the salary of the night watchman at the St. Albert Indian Residential School.

Our Appropriation for this purpose is limited, and, as it has been found necessary to allow a grant for night watchmen at several other Indian residential schools which did not previously obtain the same, it has been found necessary to place all residential schools on the same basis. You should, therefore, notify the Principal of the St. Albert Indian Residential School that the Department will not allow any grant towards the salary of the night watchman after April 30, 1935. Payment of the grant at the same rate as formerly, viz., $40 a month, will be resumed from October 1, 1935, and will be continued until April 30, 1936.

If the Principal so desires, you may forward a voucher at the end of each month during the period for which this letter authorizes the employment of a night watchman.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

We take the liberty of recalling the kind consideration with which you favored our Institution during your greatly appreciated visit of last July. The number of children has considerably increased this year and we hope that the term will prove beneficial to all.

As the girls are engaged in Manual Work during half of the day the sewing machines now in use will not meet the demand and your generous offer regarding three new sewing machines has been enthusiastically received. Treadle machines have to be used as electricity is not available in the afternoon. One Taylor machine would be of very great usefulness.

Will you also permit us to mention the 'Battleship' linoleum spoken of for our kitchen. We respectfully submit these requests to your benevolence hoping that in return the children will show their gratitude by obtaining a higher standing of education, in which you take such a deep interest.

Thanking you for your devotedness to the welfare of our Institution, we beg to remain, dear Sir,

Very respectfully yours,

St. Albert Indian Res. School

I have Mr. Pratt's memorandum of the 2nd instant, with letter attached from the Sister Superior of the St. Albert Indian Residential School, addressed to Mr. James A. MacKinnon, M. P., requesting that the Department purchase a truck for the use of the school.

In this connection I would say that this school is a church-owned institution, to which Indian children are admitted. The Department provides a grant for the education and maintenance of 160 children, for which payment is made at the rate of $180 per capita, less 15%.

It is not the policy of the Department to provide a truck for use at church-owned schools. In any event, there are no funds available to provide the cost of supplying a truck.

As requested, the letter of the Sister Superior is returned herewith.

Deputy Superintendent General.
Sir,

I beg to inform you that a short time ago I inspected St. Albert School, near Edmonton, and while there the Sister Superior wanted to know if the Department were going to help the school out in any way over and above the grant. What she asked for was some tools, as they have men at the school now who has charge of the boys and is giving them some manual training. She also asked for some paint for interior decorating and a group of 16 basins, 8 on each side, for one of the dormitories. This would cost something like $300.00.

I did not make any promises to the Sister Superior any more than that I would submit the matter to the Department. I shall be glad to be advised of the Department's decision in this matter.

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.

The Secretary,

Sir:

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 5th instant with reference to the night watchman at the St. Albert Indian Residential School.

I realize that the Reverend Sisters in charge of this institution will have to comply with the Provincial regulations regarding the wages paid to the night watchman. At the same time I would point out that we have never questioned any of the schools regarding the amount they have been paying the night watchman. We simply allow an amount of $40.00 a month for a certain period each year toward the wages of the night watchman. It has always been understood that if it is not possible to secure a night watchman for the amount we allow that the school authorities are expected to pay the balance. I may also add that the amount allowed the St. Albert School for night watchman's services is the same as that paid to other Residential Schools where night watchmen are necessary. I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 29th ultimo, enclosing copy of a letter received from the Principal of the Youville Indian Residential School.

In connection with this school, the Department found it possible to provide in the current year's appropriation an amount of $800.00 only, for repairs, improvements and new equipment. The cost of the number of desks mentioned in the Sister's letter would greatly exceed this amount.

Please find enclosed copy of letter which I have received from Rev Sister V. M. Corriveau, Principal, Youville Residential School, St. Albert. This letter is self explanatory.

Dear Sirs:

Our power plant including the heating and electrical equipment as well as the laundry and kitchen apparatus, at the School, has been inspected by Mr. Charles E. Garnett, M.E.I.C., professional engineer, (Alberta). His report states that, in his opinion, our "present method of producing heat and power is extremely inefficient." At the time the original equipment was installed, the system adopted was the only solution to the power problem. At the present time, however, due to the construction of an electric power transmission line to our premises, he declares that a very substantial saving can be made by bringing about a change in the electrical and heating systems of the Institution.

The changeover from Direct Current power obtained from our own plant to Alternating Current as supplied by the Calgary Power Company, requires the installation of motors, switches, wiring, etc. Tenders have been invited for the alterations and additions to the existing water supply and heating system as well as for the electrical work. We realize that it will be impossible to carry over the change with less than $567.00 which is the lowest bid.

As we know with what interest the Department looks upon the development of its Indian schools, we take the liberty of asking its help to finance this enterprise. Our means being so limited, we would greatly appreciate an endeavour on your part to second our efforts in this undertaking.

Trusting that our demand will receive the kind consideration of your Department, I remain, Sirs,

Respectfully yours,

Sister V.M. Corriveau,

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Your well known benevolence and devoted interest in our Indian Residential Schools must be my apology for asking you a great favor.

Our school built in 1919 is in urgent need of repairs. We are presently renewing the entire roof and this taxes our financial situation to the extreme.

The interior of the buildings require likewise urgent repairs. Among these, the cement of the basement halls is badly broken and needs to be covered or remade. We therefore, beg respectfully submit our request for help to finance this last undertaking. We would appreciate a heavy marboleum, as this is durable and would prevent the raising of dust and favor cleanliness especially for the playrooms and dining-rooms which are adjacent.

Allow me to state the dimensions of the corridors to be thus covered, as your devotedness to Indian schools cannot permit us to foresee the possibility of a refusal under present conditions—380 ft. x 7 ft.

I feel confident that you will favor our request and accept to present it to the kind consideration of your Department.

Yours very respectfully,

Sister Ste Sabine,
Principal.
Ottawa,
July 20, 1943.

Reverend and dear Sister:

I have your letter of the 5th instant, requesting us to supply marboleum for the floors of the halls in the Youville Residential School. The quantity of marboleum which you request amounts to 240 square yards. This article is not only scarce but expensive at the present time and its cost would be much more than we could provide this year. As a matter of fact we have in our appropriation an amount of $250.00 for repairs and improvements at the Youville School and this is the total amount that we can expend. I understand that we could secure Grade AA battleship linoleum at approximately $2.00 a square yard. This would mean that for the amount of funds available we would be able to secure approximately 125 square yards. However, we can only secure battleship linoleum in 6' widths. I should appreciate your advising if the linoleum mentioned would be suitable.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Memorandum to:

Dr. H.W. McGill

The Purchasing Agent has submitted to me a requisition for the purchase of battleship linoleum for the R.C. Indian Residential School at St. Albert, Alberta, the cost being $246.44, this being the lowest tender submitted.

It is noted that on the requisition it is stated that in the current year's appropriation an amount of $250 was provided for repairs and improvements at this school. Is it not the general practice to use this appropriation for repairs to the buildings rather than for buying furniture or other similar articles. The fact that the above sum is allotted to this school does not necessarily mean that it should be spent. If we adopt the policy of purchasing linoleum and carpets, this might be extended to buying other furnishings which should be purchased by the churches rather than by the Department. It would seem desirable that our expenditures should be restricted to repairs which will keep the buildings in good shape.

Memorandum:

MR. JACKSON

I am in receipt of your memorandum of August 28, with reference to the battleship linoleum requested for the Youville Indian Residential School at St. Albert, Alberta. This school is owned and operated by the Grey Nuns for the education of Indian children only.

The last expenditure made for repairs, improvements or purchase of new equipment for this school was made during the fiscal year 1939-40, at which time we purchased 31 desks at a total cost of $246.25. During the fiscal years 1940-41 and 1941-42 we did not make any expenditures at this school for either repairs, improvements or purchase of new equipment. The only payments made to them were the per capita grant and an allowance for seven months of each year for the night watchman.

In a letter received from the Principal she stated that the school was built in 1919 and this year required an entire new roof which the school management was supplying from their own funds. She also pointed out that the interior of the building required some repairs and these repairs also were being paid from their own funds. She made the special request, however, that we supply the linoleum, as this would prevent the raising of dust and favour cleanliness.

In view of the information contained in this memorandum, I trust that you will find it possible to approve the purchase of the linoleum.

Acting Director.

On my periodical visits to Youville Indian Residential School I have noted that the walls & woodwork in the dormitories & classrooms are greatly in need of paint & Kalsomine.

I mentioned this along with several other things to the Rev. Sister Vincent, the Principal and she said they simply did not have the money to do the work. She also pointed out a lot of partitioning which had been done this summer to make things more comfortable for the children, in that the bigger girls & boys were in some measure separated from the younger ones, which I thought was rather a good idea.

On looking through the estimates to find if anything had been provided for by way of repairs & maintenance, I found that the building was the property of the church. I noted also that they were only being allowed the same per capita grant as the Edmonton School & in view of this I was wondering if the Department would consider furnishing the material for re-decorating if those in charge of the school would agree to do the work.

I did not take any measurements, as I thought there would not be any object in doing so, until I found out if the Department would consider any such expenditure.

Dear Mr Phelan:

In regard of our yearly appropriation for the year 1947, may we ask again a "duplicate" purchase order No 10922 grade A Marbolem Pattern M same as last year. There were 130 square yards.

The Blowey-Henry Company of Edmonton, Alberta are ready to supply us with these goods if you give them the authorisation to do so. The price of last year's order was $3.00 per sq. yd. layed, but now in view of an increase in price the first of the year the new basis will be $3.25 per sq. yd. including also all other material and labor. We are indeed very grateful to the Company for the good material they supplied us with and they surely did a fine job.

In order to proceed with the deal the Company as above mentioned will expect an order from your Department confirming these arrangements and we sincerely hope that our request will be granted.

Thanking you in advance for this and your usual kind consideration at all times.

We remain,

Very gratefully yours,

[Signature]
Principal.

Youville Indian Residential School

In view of the fact that the Department will no longer be using this school for Indian pupils, it is requested that you interview the Reverend Principal with regard to the taking of an inventory of all Departmentally owned equipment in this school.

Any items such as linoleum, etc., which are in place should, of course, not be listed, but such items as desks, beds, etc., should be accounted for.

We have not provided many major items of equipment at this school in some years. You should inquire, however, concerning the following items:

(a) 2 filing cabinets,

(b) 2 sewing machines - supplied Oct. 30, 1946,

(c) 50 gallons of white paint, etc., supplied June, 1948.

(Please find attached account covering this paint.)

It is suggested that these items be shipped to either the Edmonton Residential School or to the Ermineskin Residential School.
The school books, pencils, library books, etc., can be shipped to either the Michel or Stony Plain Schools. Some of the desks can also be stored for use in the projected Alexander School.

I would recommend that you have the two teachers of the Michel and Stony Plain Schools visit the Youville School and arrange for them to take over the text books, scribblers, etc., such as they require. Other stocks of text books left over can then be shipped to the Ermineskin school.

We will expect a report from you in due course concerning this matter.

A letter has been sent to the Reverend Principal advising her of this matter.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

Re: Nouville Indian Residential School

The Superintendent of Education has answered my letter of the 16th, file 110-6-7, copy of which was sent to you. In this he asks that we interview local contracting firms for the submission of contracts on either firm or cost plus 10% basis.

Respecting the Alexander's Day School, a prior letter was received from Mr. Neary to say that the Chief Engineer of our Department had considered the tender of the Alberta Construction Company in the amount of $17,985.00 for the erection of the school was more than he was prepared to recommend since there was only one tender.

There is a very definite urgency for a school on the Alexander's Reserve, and possibly you can secure more tenders to erect it. Would you please advise if you may expect to get other tenders?

You might again interview the principals of the Alberta Construction Company and ascertain -

1. If they can quote a lesser amount.
2. When they would be prepared to commence the work if their company was fortunate enough in getting this job.

You may possibly find that the Alberta Construction Company tender is the best that can be secured, and though it now appears excessive to the Departmental Engineer, the price may not be at all out of line with existing building costs.

As you are fully aware of the urgency, I know that you will give this your immediate attention. To avoid any undue delay, send a copy of your reply to the Superintendent of Education. A copy of this letter is being submitted to him.

G. H. Gooderham,

Dec. 23, 1937

THE DEPUTY MINISTER

Mr. Jas. A. MacKinnon, M.P., Edmonton, with covering letter of Dec. 20, has sent the Minister a letter from Mr. Runnalls of Edmonton, with respect to land known as the Indian Residential School Farm, near St. Albert, copy of which is attached.

Ottawa, December 28, 1937.

Memorandum:

The Deputy Minister,

I have for acknowledgment Mr. Pratt's memorandum of December 23rd and also copy of a letter received by James A. MacKinnon, I.F., from Mr. Rummalls, attached thereto. Mr. Rummalls, in his letter, refers to a portion of land near St. Albert and is anxious to know if the Government would be prepared to sell this property.

I may state that the St. Albert Indian Residential School and the land surrounding this institution are the property of the church authorities. Apart from the fact that the Department pays a per capita grant to this institution, we have no ownership or control over the property at St. Albert.

In addition to the property at St. Albert, there is the farm adjoining the school known as the Edmonton Indian Residential School, operated under the auspices of the United Church of Canada. Inquiries have been made on more than one occasion with respect to the land attached to the Edmonton school and the willingness of the Government to sell a portion of this land. The Edmonton school has an enrolment of 150 pupils. The Department has always been opposed to the sale of any portion of the land known as the Edmonton Indian Residential School farm.

Statement of Joe Adams

I have always considered myself a Protestant and was educated in the Protestant school at Red Deer, Alta. I have always attended the Protestant church & have never attended the Roman Catholic church. I do not remember being baptized in the Catholic Church but I have been told that I was. I am still a Protestant & have not confessed the Catholic faith. I have one boy named John who is attending the Edmonton Residential School at the present time. The reason my boy Daniel went instead to the St. Albert School was that at the time he should have gone to school I was busy buying & selling my grain & I did not have time to take the boy to the school. When the Catholic priest Father Kenison came to meet me he told me that he had spoken to the agent & that I could send my boy to which school I liked, & did not see the Indian agent at the time, but as I was busy & could not go to the school myself & I was afraid that if I did not send the boy I would be sent to gaol, I let Father Kenison take the boy, at the same time I told Father Kenison that I did not want the boy baptized into the Catholic faith, he said alright. I had been instructed by farming Instructor Mr. Kerr to send my boy to

UNITED CHURCH OF CANADA
EDMONTON
ALBERTA

January 14th 1936.

The Secretary;
Department of Indian Affairs;
Ottawa.

Dear Sir;

May I again refer the Department to my letter of November 28th 1935 and your reply of December 5th 1935.

Re-case of Daniel Adams, son of Joe Adams, now in the St. Albert Residential School.

Quite apart from the particular case of this boy, I feel that by allowing this boy to remain at the St. Albert School will establish a most unsatisfactory precedent. As stated in my letter the boy comes from a Protestant home and the parents are still Protestant. This Paul's Band is historically Protestant and quite apart from vacillations one way and another the United Church ministers to the people regularly through a resident Missionary. This is the one Band in the whole of the Edmonton Agency where the United Church pretends to secure recruits for this school. It hardly seems fair that the Roman Catholic Priest should go into one of our homes, and take a child, and be allowed to secure this child just because he brings sufficient pressure of a religious nature upon an ignorant and susceptible Indian parent. I may say that reports from the reserve indicate that this pressure is being used and as in this case right over the head of the Agent, as the child was landed at St Albert, just after the parents had told both the Agent and our Missionary that the boy was coming here.

It may also be pointed out that the clause in the Indian Act provides that Protestant should go to Protestant schools etc., I take it
that such a clause was inserted to overcome the friction which must necessarily result from the well known unstable and fickle nature of the Indian. In other words the Department must make up its mind for the Imix Indian. It would appear that this case very definitely breaks down this idea. The father states that the other children are to come to this school, but one can see that this same battle must be fought over again when the other children come of school age. The same pressure will again be at work, and yet the parents are definitely Protestant.

Some time ago, a child from the Edmonton Agency was brought to this school by its parents, the said parents being anxious to have the child here. After objections the child was sent to the other school, on the basis that all the antecedents of the child were R.C. Again a child was sent from Hobbema by the agent because R.C. parents wished him in this school. I was instructed to return the child to Hobbema. And did so. In trying to carry out the wishes of the Department I have as far as I know not taken a child off any reserve without first securing the consent of the Agent. A few days ago at Hobbema I was advised of a boy (Baptiste) who wished to come to this school. I phoned the Agent, he requested me not to take the child until certain matters were settled. I respected his wishes. I have always done so in the case of Mr. Laight. I do not think it fair that another school officer should go into our homes and thus disregard the instructions of the Department-to our disadvantage. This religious competition disgusts and humiliates me and I hesitate to quarrel over a little Indian lad, but if we are ever to solve this delicate matter there must be some respect for the rights of others. And as stated in the first place I feel that if allowed to pass this case will form an unfortunate precedent. These Wabamun Indians are a very low and ignorant lot, and if allowed to settle matters themselves will be sending part of their family one place and the rest another place. There are a few trouble makers among the Indian people on this
Joe House is one. He denies it of course, but for some time we have felt it. When I say "we" I mean more than our Missionary people. I quite appreciate the fact that the Department has difficulty in determining the rights of the case, and I have been satisfied with most of the decisions of the Department. I also wish to say that the Indian Agent, Mr. Laight, has been fair and impartial, but I frankly think that this case if allowed to pass will bring no end of confusion to the work at Wabamun, and involve future cases.

I have written very frankly, and as I view the case, I may be all wrong, but I do not think this case should be decided at once or without very serious consideration. I am speaking for the school and the church, as well as in the light of previous regulations and instructions of the Department.

All the above is very respectfully submitted.

Yours Truly,

[Signature]
Principal.

RE: Daniel Adams.

I wish to state that in the early part of 1935 I was requested by Joe Adams of Paul's Reserve to make application to have his children educated at St. Albert. Joe stated that his parents were both Catholics and that he believed himself to have been baptized by a priest. I investigated and discovered that he was baptized in the Catholic font when quite young.

In the autumn of 1935 Joe again approached me with the request that I try to place his son Dan in the convent. I promised to do what I could. The facts about his case were forwarded to the Indian Department. The reply was to the effect that he was permitted to choose in the matter of schools. I told him this and he agreed to send Dan to the convent. His later statement that he forbade me to baptize his boy is absolutely false.

I was under the impression that the boy entered the Catholic school with the approval of the Department and that Joe's decision of October 23, 1935 was supposed to be final. I am rather surprised that the boy has been taken from the Catholic school as I know the policy of the Department is not to grant the varying wishes of the Indians. I am rather amazed to have made a mistake in placing Dan in a Catholic school since this was done with the approval of the proper authorities.

I do not wish to cause unnecessary inconvenience to the Indian Department but simply to state my position and prevent misunderstanding of the case.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]

Sir:

I received a request from John Callihoo, member of the Michel Band, asking permission to place 4 of his brother Fred Callihoo's children, who are now orphans, into the St. Albert Indian Residential School. For your information I beg to state that Fred Callihoo was a Treaty Indian and also his wife. During the regime of Mr. George H. Race as Indian Agent at this Agency Fred Callihoo and his wife left Canada and were in the States for approximately 6 or 7 years. After their return to their reserve they were told by Mr. Race, that owing to their being absent and living in a foreign country for 5 years continuously that under Section 13 of the Indian Act they had ceased to be members of the Band and that they could not again become members of that Band. I am unable to get any information whether or not Mr. Race took this matter up with the Department upon the return of Fred Callihoo and, therefore, to my knowledge they were not members of the Band; during my regime as Agent.

Fred Callihoo and his wife are now dead and the children are being taken care of by their uncle Johnny Callihoo. Will you please advise me if these children may be placed in the St. Albert Residential School as grant-earning pupils?

I am Sir,

Your obedient servant,

G. C. Laight,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Re: Michael Kootenay.

I have examined Michael this morning at the Edmonton General Hospital, and I find double mastoid condition has cleared up very well, whereby he does not require any further treatment for his ears.

He has been a very sick boy, and he seems to be affected mentally, which is possibly only functional, due to his long illness.

I think he should be taken out of school and allowed to return to his people at Lac Ste Anne. His father has promised to bring him in to Dr. Conroy or myself for periodical examination within the next few weeks.

Would you be good enough to discharge him from school.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir:

It is noted that this girl is not amenable to discipline and that it is recommended by the Doctor and yourself that she be placed in the Home of the Good Shepherd, Edmonton, providing arrangements can be made for her admittance to that institution.

The Department would appreciate, if the authorities of the Home of the Good Shepherd will accept this girl, to have her placed therein. We would be prepared to allow the Home remuneration for her maintenance, clothing and tuition at the rate of $14 per month, payable quarterly, upon receipt of an account, in triplicate, which should be submitted through your office and certified by you.

It is considered that approximately one year would be a sufficient length of time for this girl to remain in the Home. You should keep in touch with her case, and, about this time next year, you should make a recommendation as to whether she should be kept in an institution or returned to her home on the reserve. In any event, we would not be prepared to continue the grant for her maintenance in the Home for a period later than March 31st, 1938.

You may take this matter up with the authorities of the Home, and if they will consent to accept her on the above terms, you may arrange to have her placed there. Please advise the Department of the action taken.

Dear Sir,

Re: Moise Ward, No. 495.

I have to inform you that Moise Ward has not responded to our zeal to foster in him moral habits. He does not openly disturb the discipline of the School; his influence is rather of a concealed form to induce other pupils to evil habits.

In a few instances in the past, I have looked forward to his discharge, but different means have been attempted to avoid taking this measure. As no improvement is perceived in his conduct, I believe I am justified in asking for his discharge.

I therefore wish to submit the matter to your kind consideration and would be very thankful if steps were taken to that effect without causing any vexation among the Indians.

Sincerely yours,

Sister V.M. Corriveau,
Sister V.M. Corriveau, superior.
Sir:

Sir:

I beg to report that Pupil No. 0564 Mary Potskin was discharged from the Youville Indian Residential School on September 30th, 1938. This girl returned to her parents who live in the Lesser Slave Lake Agency, her mother died a short time ago and the girl has returned to the Youville school. She arrived at the school last Tuesday December 20th. I would ask for authority to have her re-admitted and kept in the school until she is of the age of 18 years.

For the information of the Department I wish to state that this girl's mother was Marie Shortlegs daughter of the late Narcisse Shortlegs No. II2 Alexander Band. She married Albert Potskin, Lesser Slave Lake Agency and went to that agency to live after her marriage. Mary has stayed with her grandmother during the holidays Mrs Jacob Burnstick No. 86 Alexander Band.

I am Sir,

File References Re: Simon BRELAND - Family of:- Calahoo Reserve Assistance to, Dept. Indian Affairs.

Headquarters

1. As the result of a phone call received from Mr. LAIGHT, Indian Agent during the morning of 28-2-39 a patrol was made to the Calahoo Reserve to ascertain why the three children of the above named were not attending the school at St Albert.

Sub-Division

2. During the after-noon of 28-2-39 while en route to the home of the above named I met Chief Fred GALANDO and Simon BRELAND, they were then on their way to St Albert with Donald BRELAND age 12. I questioned Simon BRELAND and he stated that his wife would not let the children go to school but he had been able to take the one child and the other two were still at home.

Detachment

3. I continued the patrol to the BRELAND home accompanied by Chief Fred GALANDO and interviewed Mrs. BRELAND. As a result of this interview the oldest boy Alphonse age 13 years accompanied us to the school at St Albert and the girl age 7 years (Veronica) will be taken to the school on or before March 6th, by Mrs. BRELAND.

P.C.R.

4. There appeared to be no reason why Mrs. BRELAND did not want these children to go to school except that she did not want them to leave home.

5. At the present time the two boys are in the school and the girl will be taken soon. Chief GALANDO is of the opinion that no further trouble will be caused by Mrs. BRELAND.

6. Mr. LAIGHT was contacted by phone during the morning of 1-3-39 and he is satisfied with the action taken.

CONCLUDED

INDIANS' ART IS ADMIRE

Tourists Gasp at Saddle Trappings, Jackets, Gauntlets

Gay knitted gloves and beaded buckskin gauntlets are only part of the contrast between traditional and modern Indian work in the exhibit under the grandstand. The work of the students in the Indian schools is on a par, and the same in subject as that turned in by their white friends, but the showing of handcraft shows that the ancient arts are not being lost.

From tourists particularly, the buckskin jackets, gauntlets, saddle trappings with their colorful beadwork, produced drawn gasps of admiration. One individual squaw arranged her beaded earrings on a birch bark frame.

There are a number of birch bark sewing cases, some of them others with porcupine quill decorations.

The school work includes bright smocks, knitted and crocheted goods, cross-stick samplers, maps, and art work. All of these are the efforts of students from the Youville school at St. Albert and St. Mary's Roman Catholic school at Cardston.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 27th ultimo and note its contents.

I was aware that the schools would be late in opening, due to the provincial government's action in regard to epidemics. However, as you will note on the reverse of the Monthly Report, I desire a report every month even if instruction has not been given.

I am pleased to note that you will have splendid accommodation for the manual training class. Your plan, however, would not be effective. An hour period for woodwork is practically a loss of time. You will readily understand what I mean. The time that it takes the pupils to get ready and put away their tools leaves very little time for instruction. The minimum required for the course is three hours per week, but these three hours should be consecutive. This amounts to an afternoon a week.

Your impression that this is a four-year course is faulty. It is designed for a three-year course. I have no objection, however, to young boys taking the course if you judge they are able to profit by it.

For the musical training, we always had three general exercises each week beside other rehearsals for many occasions, but from now on the teachers will give the daily period as before.

It would be our utmost desire, dear Mr Phelan, to provide the children with all these beneficial trainings, but we lack the necessary financial means to do so. We give them good schooling, we watch over their health by giving them warm clothing and good food, and you know how much these commodities cost at the present time, and this is all we can afford.

You will understand that our school built in 1919, now needs repairs and alterations and it is urgent that we provide for these, before other extra expenses be encountered. The $250.00 appropriation we received annually from the Dept. is a very small portion of the large amount we had to pay for the last three years for repairs, paintings, etc. Two of the quarterly cheques do not cover the yearly interests, insurances and taxes, so it leaves us only the other half to meet all our other obligations.

May I add, Mr Phelan, that we would be most thankful to you and to your Department if you could assist us in any way to provide the means to carry on the various trainings as you desire, but without help, I am very sorry, we cannot do better.

OTTAWA.

Dear Mr Phelan:

In reply to your letters dated Dec. 31st and January 7th, permit me to state the reason why certain special trainings have not been undertaken this year. Previously, we have given the boys training in woodwork and we supplied tools and material as best we could. We cannot afford to do so this year as not only new tools and material should be supplied, but we cannot obtain the services of an instructor. An ordinary carpenter cannot be hired for less than one dollar per hour and this beyond our means.

As to farm work, we have had a great deal of trouble with the big boys in the last two years. They expect to be remunerated for the least work they do and they show such a lack of interest in all their work that the men on the farm feel they are wasting time trying to teach them. It would require a man solely to direct, and that would mean another monthly salary of $100.00.

The older girls have had their regular daily periods of training in sewing, but as to cooking we have had not enough help to teach them the regular lessons prescribed, although a few in the morning and as many in the afternoon are helping to prepare and cook the daily menus of the household, thus receiving some training. Knowing these conditions, would you kindly tell us how we should make the monthly reports as required in your letter of January 7th.

As for the Physical Training, we never had a regular instructor for either boys or girls. Mr A. Durocher has volunteered to take the boys sometime before Christmas to add an extra number to the concert given for the parents on Christmas Day. Mr Durocher will not continue giving P.T. unless he is paid to do it. We could now have a lady to give the girls the same training if proper remuneration were available.
Ottawa, January 30th, 1946.

Reverend Sister Rose Vincent, Principal, Youville Indian Residential School, St. Albert, Alberta.

I have your letter of the 27th instant and I have carefully taken note of its contents.

The Department realizes the great difficulty that some schools are facing when endeavouring to obtain qualified instructors. We also realize that due to the advanced season very little, if anything could be accomplished this year. We are anxious, however, that immediate steps be taken to improve the condition for next September. On our part, we are prepared to give you a special grant towards material needed in teaching Manual Training, provided a qualified Instructor is secured. We are also willing to help defray the salary expense of such an Instructor. I am enclosing forms which should be completed by an Instructor who might apply for the position. He should have some teaching experience, some training in general shop and be able to take charge of the boys physical training and organized games. The Department will pay half the salary provided the services of the teacher could be secured for $1500.00 a year or less; In other words, if a teacher requests $1500.00 for the academic year, this Department will allow $750.00, the School Management providing the balance of the salary plus room and board. If the salary is less than $1500.00, it is understood we would pay only half the amount. We feel that you will be able to secure the services of a qualified Instructor, as Alberta definitely trains teachers for this kind of work.

I have noticed your tool requisition. I think that it would be better to wait until you have secured an instructor then he can go into the matter of tools more carefully. He should, then, submit a requisition to us and
we will endeavour to supply the tools required for this instruction.

As regards the girls domestic science, that is, cooking, sewing, knitting, etc., we can not imagine any difficulty being encountered. The Basic Operation requirements, copies of which have been sent to your school are the result of every day occupations around the school. It should not, therefore, be difficult to train the girls in these activities.

Should there be anything else that we can do to further encourage the integrated program of studies in your school, please let me know.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I have been informed that the Department of Indian Affairs sends, upon request, goats for the Residential School farms, with instructions as to the way of proceeding to spread this beneficial industry among the Indians.

I wrote to our Indian Agent, Mr. G.C. Laight, last week, asking him if he thought it advisable to request a certain number for our farm.

In answer, he suggested that I write direct to you, Mr. Hoey. This, I confidently do today, as I know you have always shown a keen interest in the welfare of our school, and have always done your utmost to foster its further development. May I hope that you will add to your favors, that of kindly bringing this request before your Department?

Allow me, dear Mr. Hoey, to renew our most sincere thanks for your kind concern in our Institution and its inmates.

Yours very respectfully,

Sister Rose Vincent, S.G.M.
Sister R. Vincent,
Principal.
Ottawa, August 5, 1944.

Mr. C. P. Schmidt, Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Calgary, Alberta.

I am sending forward herewith copy of a letter received by this Branch from the Principal of the Youville Indian Residential School. The subject matter of this communication, you will note, is self-explanatory.

It is my understanding that it is somewhat difficult to secure goats for the time being anywhere in Alberta and only a little less difficult to secure them in the province of British Columbia. If, however, goats are anywhere available at a reasonable price, you are authorized to purchase five female and one male goat for the use of the Youville School. I am not at all sure that this is the best season of the year to make such a purchase. It is just possible that goats for our schools should be purchased early in the spring. I make this suggestion for the simple reason that they require less care during the spring, summer and fall months than they do during the winter. However, this is a matter in respect to which you can exercise your own best judgment. If you are at Edmonton at any time in the immediate future, you might discuss this matter personally with the Principal of the Youville School.

Encl.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa, August 5, 1944.

My dear Sister:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of July 31, in which you express a desire to undertake the feeding and care of a number of goats at your school.

I may state that our policy in providing a limited number of goats at residential schools represents an attempt to provide instruction to Indian pupils, particularly the senior boys and girls, in the care and feeding of goats. We have been informed by the best nutritionists in the country that it is exceedingly difficult, if not impossible, to supply a well balanced diet for Indians, particularly Indian children, in the absence of milk. In view of the fact, therefore, that it is not practicable to keep cows on a number of the smaller reserves, we have deemed it advisable to encourage certain bands of Indians to keep goats.

I am sending forward herewith, for your information, copy of a letter addressed by me to Inspector Schmidt. It is altogether likely that the Inspector will take the steps necessary to purchase a few goats for your school, if such goats are available.

May I embrace this opportunity to thank you very heartily for the words of appreciation contained in your communication.

Yours sincerely,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Rev. Sister Rose Vincent, S.G.M.,
Principal,
Youville Indian Residential School,
St. Albert, Alberta.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in quarter of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The grant per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September, and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter."

9. The amount of capital grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, putting it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of the Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively; and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days present of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter."

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Return must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payments be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Return must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total" for each pupil during quarter.

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The quarterly per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.
