Ottawa, October 5th, 1923.

Rev. Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 10th ultimo, furnishing a list of the desks required for the use of St. Bernard's Residential School.

In reply I beg to say it is noted that you request that 40 desks of the sizes mentioned in your letter be supplied. I would point out that the Department allows a per capita grant to your school for 30 pupils, and we can supply desks for that number only. Kindly state the condition and kind of desks at present in use in your school, and the number of same that are serviceable. You may forward a requisition for the number - not exceeding 30 - required to replace the desks that are not in good condition, and you should also give the ages of the children for whom the new desks are required. Please also give full shipping directions. As soon as we have this information we will be in a position to decide the number of desks that can be allowed.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Dear Sir:

We know how eager the Department of Indian Affairs is to provide its schools with everything for their proper management and equipment.

Probably the most important question in connection with any establishment is the water supply. In our case this has always been a source of drudgery, inconvenience and great expense, which can be readily understood when one considers that the water has to be hauled up hill from the river at an altitude of 200 feet.

In our endeavours to better the situation, we have never gone beyond the plans which would be to establish a system whereby water might be pumped from the river; but our means are not adequate to the scheme and we do not foresee the possibility of carrying it out unless help comes from some other quarter.

It occurred to me that the Department might see here an opportunity for helping a good cause and if it were so inclined what a boon it would mean for the school and how greatly the favour would be appreciated by all concerned.

Trusting that my hopes may be realized regarding this important project,

I remain, Sir, your respectful servant.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Scott,

A request has been made to this office by the Reverend Father Guy, and to you personally by the Reverend Principal Father Floch of the St. Bernard's Indian Residential School at Grouard, Alberta, for some assistance towards the installation of a water supply system for this institution. The water is now pumped into the building from an artesian well and is not serviceable on account of its hardness, and is a source of great expense to the management of the school. The water for the laundry and the cooking is carted from the river a distance of 1500 feet and to an altitude of 150 feet, which means a lot of hardship. The average amount of water required is 1500 gallons.

I have prepared for your information an estimate of the cost of an installation which will provide for sixty persons consisting of a typhoon pressure pump of a capacity of 40 gallons per minute operated by a three H.P. oil engine. This pumping outfit could be installed in a small building erected on top of an intake well close to the shore of the river, a distance of about 1300 feet from the nearest building. The water would be pumped into a tank in one of the buildings, which would provide for a quantity of water sufficient for domestic purposes only. The cost of the machinery would be $550.00. The two inch galvanized iron pipe and fittings for connection to the water tank and the various buildings would cost $500.00. The intake well and the machinery building would cost $500.00, making a total $1,550.00.

In view of the fact that this school is not the property of the Department I would suggest that the above mentioned equipment be granted by the Department, on condition that the Principal will arrange for all the labour required, such as the excavating work, the laying of pipe and the installation of machinery, etc., which will represent an expenditure of at least $3,000.

As mentioned in the Principal's letter of July 18th, this institution has no means to pay the cost of such an installation.........

January 9, 1926.

Memorandum:

Honourable Charles Stewart,

St. Bernard's Indian Residential School, near Grouard, Alta., has urgent need of a proper water supply system. At the present time, all water required for washing and cooking is hauled from a river some 1500 ft. distant.

The school management and the Church authorities have urged the Department to install a pressure pump and gas engine in a small building above an intake well at the shore and to supply a pipe to the school water tank. The well, building and machinery will cost $1650. I propose to ask the school management to be responsible for the excavation, laying of the pipe, installation of the machinery and all other labour the cost of which is estimated by the Department engineer, who has outlined the proposed scheme, at approximately $3,000. If the school authorities are willing to undertake the work, I consider the Department should allow the $1650 necessary for machinery and materials. I shall be pleased to have your approval of the expenditure. Funds are available in the Appropriation for Indian Education.

Duncan C. Scott

January 9, 1926.

Honourable Charles Stewart,

St. Bernard's Indian Residential School, near Crowfoot, Alta., has urgent need of a proper water supply system. At the present time, all water required for washing and cooking is hauled from a river some 1800 ft. distant.

The school management and the Church authorities have urged the Department to install a pressure pump and gas engine in a small building above an intake well at the shore and to supply a pipe to the school water tank. The well, building and machinery will cost $1650. I propose to ask the school management to be responsible for the excavation, laying of the pipe, installation of the machinery and all other labour the cost of which is estimated by the Department engineer, who has outlined the proposed scheme, at approximately $3,000. If the school authorities are willing to undertake the work, I consider the Department should allow the $1650 necessary for machinery and materials. I shall be pleased to have your approval of the expenditure. Funds are available in the Appropriation for Indian Education.

Dear Sir:

You are well acquainted with our Residential School at Grouard. You yourself know as also the numerous tourists who have favored us with their visits, that what we call the boys' department is a very old building. It was built with lors thirty-six years ago, very satisfactory at the time, but has now become dangerous and unsanitary for the inmates. It is for this reason that I beg you to kindly use your influence with the department in regard to this request, namely to construct a new building for the boys according to the enclosed plan and estimate. It will be simple, very comfortable, and not too expensive. We will help in the expenditures.

I rely on your devotedness which has always been shown towards the Indians. I am confident that you will assist us to obtain our request, and that next year we will be able to construct a building which will speak in favor of your department.

Yours sincerely,

ST. BERNARD'S INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (R.C.) GROUARD.

I visited this school on the 16th of February, and made a general inspection of the buildings.

There are 71 pupils enrolled, 32 boys and 39 girls. Four classrooms are provided, and each in charge of a qualified teacher. The Sisters of Providence have charge of the inside work, and it was noted

W. Morrison,
Inspector of Indian Affairs
ST. BERNARD'S INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (R.C.) Cont'd.

mending and knitting of socks is done by the girls.

I was very pleased with the appearance and manner of the children. I enquired into the question of food supplied to the children, and I am informed that they get all the milk they care to have, and are given wholesome, nourishing food. Their general appearance is healthy and would indicate that they are well cared for.

Twelve cows are kept for milking purposes, and a small home farm is operated in close proximity to the school. They raise hogs and poultry. There were 20 hogs on hand at the time of my visit. The home farm consists of 50 acres for grain, 4 acres for potatoes, and a large garden. They have a large farm about 9 miles away which is operated with hired help, and the young stock is kept there. Only the cows required for milking purposes are kept at the school. They have over 120 cattle altogether.

The Rev. Father Floch is in charge as Principal. He has two lay brothers and a number of hired help. The Principal appears to be very energetic and interested in the welfare of his school.

noted that all the members of the staff speak good English.

Separate buildings are provided for the boys and the girls. The main building is frame, and provides a kitchen, dining rooms, office, infirmary, girls' dormitory, and staff rooms. It is heated with hot air and lighted with electricity. Fire extinguishers are placed at convenient points throughout the building, and there are stairway escapes at each end of the building. The dormitory in this building is large, and it is noted that comfortable beds are provided. Wash basins and individual towels are provided in the dormitory. This building is in good condition.

The boys' building is very old, being one of the first buildings erected at this Mission. The lumber, for the most part, used in its construction was whip sawed by hand. Stairways are provided at each end of the building as a means of escape in the event of fire. Fire extinguishers are also placed in this building at easily accessible places. This building is not in good condition, has served its purpose, and should be replaced. It is heated with stoves and lighted with electricity.

Separate outside toilets are provided for the boys and for the girls. I found these in good condition.

The water supply is pumped from the lake in the summer months, but as they only use a surface pipe, they have to haul their water supply during the winter months.

Dear Mr Ferrier:

When in Ottawa lately I discussed with you the feasibility of the construction of a new boys' wing at St Bernard's Indian Residential School.

I understand that $5000.00 will be voted in Parliament for that purpose. When in Ottawa I told you that we would rather wait and ask later for a substantial building for both boys and girls. You quite agreed with me as you could make use of whatever money was not used for the purpose for which it would be voted. We were only to repair the present building and wait a year or two. I regret to say that in spite of my good will it will be impracticable to repair the present boys' wing decently. Mr Hurison who has inspected it in January has probably voiced my sentiment. I presume our agent would agree with me. We therefore take the liberty of proposing to build a frame building 60' x 40' x 10' or 12' just one story to be used only for military purposes, said building to be used later as a gymnasium or auditorium when the other building will be erected. With such a building we could wait a few years and thus accommodate you better. We would keep the present building as a recreation, refectory and even class room(1) building. Of course the present building would have to be repaired. All the floors would have to be renewed and a few minor details looked after. I wish to note also that the roof is leaking. A few rolls of tar paper would do to cover the whole building.

The new building would be heated by camp stoves or if the Department prefers it by two pipeless furnaces. In the latter case the expense would be a little higher. There would be no toilet as same would be located outside as at present, the children being used to such discomfort.

It is our belief that we would not spend much more than the amount allotted and we therefore ask the advice and authority of the Department to proceed immediately with the work.

I may add that we are in need of a vegetable cellar at Grouard. If we were installing pipeless furnaces for the above building we would have to dig for installing said furnaces and could profit by this opportunity to make a concrete basement for furnaces and also for vegetables cellar.

I will reach Grouard on the 27th and would welcome an answer at that point at your earliest opportunity.

Yours very truly,

Memorandum:

HONOURABLE THOMAS G. MURPHY

Five Thousand Dollars is available for the construction of a new boys' wing at the St. Bernard's Indian Residential School, approximately 35 miles across Lesser Slave Lake from Ground, Alta., in the federal district of Peace River. The church authorities are urging the construction of a temporary frame building of one storey only, to be used for the next few years as a boys' dormitory. Later, when a modern main building has been erected, it is suggested that the proposed frame building be converted into a gymnasium or workshops. This scheme commends itself to me.

The usual practice in the case of northern schools is to have the church authorities undertake the construction of inexpensive buildings and to present accounts for material and labour up to the amount of the Department's grant. In this manner, considerable saving is nearly always effected. With your concurrence, I shall draft a memorandum to Council, authorizing a grant of $5,000 to the church authorities towards the cost of erecting this building.

His Excellency

The Governor General in Council,

The undersigned has the honour to report that the boys' wing at the St. Bernard's Indian Residential School, approximately 35 miles across Lesser Slave Lake from Crowfoot, Alberta, in the federal district of Peace River, has fallen into disrepair and is no longer suitable for use. The Oblate Order under whose auspices the school is conducted proposes the construction of a temporary frame building of one storey only, to be used for the next few years as a boys' dormitory. Later, when a modern main building has been erected, it is suggested that the proposed frame building be converted into a gymnasium or workshops.

An amount of $5000.00 as a grant by the Department of Indian Affairs toward the cost of erecting this building has been provided by Parliament for the current fiscal year 1931-32.

The usual practice in the case of northern schools is to have the church authorities undertake the construction of inexpensive buildings and to present accounts for material and labour up to the amount of the department's grant. In this manner, considerable saving is usually effected.

The undersigned accordingly has the honour to recommend that authority be granted for the expenditure of the said sum of $5000.00 for the purpose above mentioned.

Right Reverend Sir:

With reference to Your Lordship's letter of June 15th, I have to confirm official Day Letter of this date, as follows:

"Reference Your Lordship's letter June fifteenth, re building to be used as boys' dormitory for time being at St. Bernard's Indian Residential School, authority now received for Five Thousand Dollar grant. This will be paid when Your Lordship forwards usual receipts for materials and time sheets, both in duplicate, showing that at least the amount has been expended for the building."

I may say that P.C. 1937, of the 14th instant, authorizes a grant of $5,000. It is understood that the Church authorities will erect a frame building, as specified in Your Lordship's letter; that this building will be used as a boys' dormitory for the time being and that, at a later date, it will be for gymnasium or auditorium or workshop, etc. The Department considers that box stoves would be suitable for heating this building. I cannot concur in the preparation of a root cellar underneath it, as this would make it unsuitable for the purposes to which it is to be put.

Your Lordship will see that receipted accounts for the material and time sheets for the labour - both in duplicate- are forwarded in due course. If these show an expenditure of at least $5,000, grant up to this amount can be allowed. When this work is under way, if Your Lordship would like an advance on the grant, please make application.

I have the honour to be,

Right Reverend Sir,

At the request of His Lordship Bishop Guy, the Department is today placing an order with the Pyrene Mfg. Co. of Canada Ltd., Toronto, to ship addressed to you for use at the St. Bernard's Indian Residential School, the following fire extinguishers:

Memorandum:

MR. BUSKARD,

The Main Estimates, Indian Education, provide funds to reimburse the church authorities for expenses incurred for the water supply and for the furnishings at the St. Bernard's Indian Residential School, near Grouard, Alta. The work and purchase has all been done, but, previous to giving Bishop Guy any authority, he was given the names of firms that were acceptable.

His Lordship was informed that the Parkhill Bedding Company, of Winnipeg, were satisfactory and he made excellent arrangements with them, but I find the account is presented from the Edmonton branch of this firm. The Parkhill Bedding, Limited, of Edmonton, do not appear on the list, and I shall be glad to learn if the Minister approves of sending them a cheque. The amount involved for the 78 beds, mattresses and pillows complete is $1,168.58, or an average of $15.24 for each outfit.

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

I would suggest that an amount be included in the estimates in view of helping us in this work. You know how afflicted we have been with fires. Last year we lost the hospital and girls building at Fort Vermilion School and have not been helped to any serious extent by the Department. I have done my best under circumstances to weather the situation, borrowing money to erect a building and spending the greater part of my time, literally begging to pay the interest. I would suggest $10,000 for said buildings.

In the Estimates you will also find the following:

$6,000 to reimburse us for the construction of an annex to the girls building at St Bernard's Indian Residential School. As in the case of Fort Vermilion I borrowed the money and have been begging to pay the interest. I have all vouchers necessary to prove that the annex has cost at least the above amount;

$5,000 for the same purpose at Fort Vermilion;

December 4th, 1933.

Dear Bishop Guy,

Your letter of November 28th, reached me on Friday, December 1st. I was very sorry indeed to hear that you had met the ill fortune of illness and had been confined to the St. Boniface Hospital. Please allow me to express my pleasure at the news of your recovery which I trust will be both complete and permanent.

After the receipt of your letter there was not time for me to reach you by telegram before your departure from the hospital, but you will have received by now the telegram sent you on December 2nd.

The news in your letter was the first we had had with regard to the fire at Grouard. I have since seen the news item in the papers giving the particulars, but I am not aware that we have yet received any official notification from our agent.

I took up the matter of the immediate replacement of equipment at once with the Honourable the Superintendent General, and the telegram sent you to Edmonton embodied the instructions he gave. We shall take measures to dispose of the matter promptly upon receipt of the information required.

With kindest personal regards and best wishes for the coming Christmas and New Year Seasons, I am,

Yours faithfully,

Rt. Rev. Joseph Guy, C.M.I.,
Bishop of Grouard,

Harold W. McGill.
Sir,

Further to my telegram of same date, re St. Bernard Schools and St. Joseph Hospital of Grouard recently destroyed by fire.

On Sunday the 26th, about at 2 o'clock P.M. during an awful wind and snow storm, the St. Joseph Hospital caught fire and the flames spread so rapidly that the Sister in charge scarcely had time to get out with her patients, but nobody got injured, and in no time the whole town of Grouard was on the scene fighting the flames but the wind was blowing so hard that it was impossible to check the fire for some time. Beside the Hospital, two school houses and another small building were completely destroyed and a couple of desks and a few books are all that what saved from the fire. Since it was impossible to do anything to save the Hospital and the schools all the efforts of the people were directed towards the Fathers' residence and the Convent, and it is useless to say that it was a desperate fight, but they succeeded to check the fire and those buildings were only badly scorched.

I did not hear about this fire until Monday in the afternoon, as the telephone line got damaged during the storm by the falling trees, so on Tuesday morning I went to Grouard to inquire what assistance they needed. The Rev. Father Superior and Sisters looked very despondent and they did not asked for anything beside drugs, as all the ir medical supplies were lost in the fire, but there is no doubt that they will ask for assistance later on. The origin of the fire is not known.

Your obedient servant,

N.P. L'Heureux,
Indian Agent.

Dear Doctor McGill:

At last I am given an opportunity of giving a report on the fire that destroyed a few of our buildings at Grouard, on Nov. 26th, together with a list of our losses.

The agent must have reported to you as he told me yesterday. Fire broke out in the attic of the hospital through a defective chimney at 2.30 hrs Sunday afternoon, the 26th. Rev. Fr Charest, my secretary, who happened to be in the hospital, (as a patient) rushed upstairs with an extinguisher but was driven back by the smoke that was already spreading over the whole building. The sisters immediately brought out the few patients that were in the hospital and placed them in my residence which is at a fair distance. Some of our boys (Indian boys) tried again to stop the fire by rushing up ladders with extinguishers but to no avail. The building was doomed. Then attention was turned to saving the other buildings. There was a fierce wind blowing and as the ground was simply a mirror on account of rapid freezing after a heavy rain following a fall of snow the sparks and cinders started to travel from building to building but meanwhile the father (the principal), the brothers, the sisters and a few volunteers including our boys started to save the contents of the buildings. From school building No.1 all desks, chairs, and many books were saved. Then from School building No.2, all desks, benches, books, blackboards of the two stories were out in a short time. Part of the articles stored in the attic were saved but quite a quantity was left as can be seen on the accompanying list. I may say that a few desks were broken but I did not mention them on the list.

The laundry was first to blaze but a few articles were saved together with some clothing, then the milk house were nothing was saved, then the ice house in which there was but a few tools, then the two school buildings. Fire started many times on the boys' residence outside and inside. The sparks were passing through little holes in the windows or through windows. That accounts for the losses in the boys' residence, though farther from the fire than the girls' but the boys' residence was right in the wake of the wind. Our night watchman, Mr St Denis, did wonderful work with our boys and saved the place. Unhappily people who were coming to help us and ... others (specially women) took away quite a number of things as you can see by the annexed list. We have recovered

Dear Bishop Guy:

I have your letter of the 11th instant, reporting on the loss incurred by fire at the St. Bernard's Indian Residential School on the 26th ultimo. The loss occasioned is regretted, but I am pleased to learn that, through the strenuous efforts of the staff, there was no loss of life and that the two main buildings and also considerable equipment were saved. I have noted the list which you submit, of the various articles that were destroyed, and that you request the Department to reimburse the school authorities or replace the loss.

I am not definitely aware, from your letter, what new equipment will be required to enable the school to carry on or the approximate cost of same. An order has been sent the Government Stationery Office to forward the classroom material considered necessary, and a quantity of fire extinguishers will be ordered and sent the school.

OTTAWA, Ont.

My Dear Doctor McGill:

Your letter of December 20th, 1933, duly received. The rush of Christmas mail has delayed my answer to this day.

I must say that I felt rather sad on perusal of same. I really believed that the Department would do something special in the present instance. I understand that no money was voted in the Estimates for such an emergency case but my past experience in the Department teaches me that emergency cases can be met with. You will realize, Doctor McGill, that two fires in almost rapid succession should obtain consideration from the higher authorities of the Department. I have not the privilege of knowing personally the Honorable the Superintendent General for the very simple reason that I have always dealt satisfactorily with you personally and with other officials of the different branches of the Department, but I believe that if the case was placed before him in its entirety he would favor some means of helping us out in the present trial. Of course I could bring the matter before the Honorable the Prime Minister and you know by experience (for example Rt Rev. Bishop Charlebois' repeated appeals) that we obtain results. But again, I do not think to go to such extremes and just wish to appeal to you again and ask as I did in my preceding letter for a little help.

With this view I have prepared a complete list of all articles lost in or on account of the fire and enclose same. I would call your attention on the food lost to the extent of $679.15 ($718.50 less four last items, hospital list viz $33.35) plus $181.15 in the milk house (viz butter, lard, tea, bacon, meat, peas, molasses) making a total of $860.30. Could you not place us on the relief list for that amount and allow us either to buy in a store indicated by you or the Honorable the Superintendent General or present bills for articles bought in our regular wholesale stores?

The clothing as per list on page 3 could be attended to in the same manner as suggested for food. Other items of that kind are found in the Laundry list and school building No 2 (two last items: soap and paper).
As already stated in my previous letter we are doing our very best to carry on and in order to answer the request of paragraph 2 of your letter I may say that to carry on the school work we have received classroom material from the Department and wish to thank you for same. A teacher's desk would come handy, also the book cases and blackboard. The Dominion ensign of course we could do without but you know what it means in front of a school building.

Regarding the laundry equipment though the sisters go every other week at St Bruno's School for the regular washing we do a part of the latter here in a room back of the Bishop's Residence's kitchen. I have already bought a few necessary articles as per invoice no. 7174 of J.H. Ashdown Hardware Ltd enclosed. Those articles are for the laundry room (except the churn and butter rocker also absolutely needed for the kitchen). I did not buy the 3 boilers nor any washing machine as yet nor copper wash boiler nor the two heating stoves. I bought rosin and lye as per invoices no. 495 enclosed. We need washing machines with wringers, laundry soap, soap flakes, washing soda, Keen's Blue.

We have received Pyrene and Thermene extinguishers for which I am pleased to thank you.

Returning to your letter I note that you express the impossibility of providing the full requirements for the schools under my jurisdiction. I feel sorry for such news. In a passing way I wish to point out that in my list of articles lost I did not mention the most important of all; the losses on the buildings themselves. I would estimate same to be about $15,000.00 (with $20,000.00 on hospital, the latter belonging to the sisters' corporation and being insured to the extent of $10,000.00). Note that the articles listed under the heading Hospital belonged to the school and were only stored there through lack of space elsewhere.

Regarding the Insurance we carry or are supposed to carry at Grouard or elsewhere on the buildings of the schools I wish to say that none of our Indian Residential Schools are insured. How could we get the money to pay the premiums when specially in our Northern country said premiums are almost prohibitive. However, I may say that in the case of the boys' building at Grouard which was built two years ago I took an insurance policy of $8,000.00 just for the building in order to protect same during the construction. This policy will elapse on November 13th, 1934. In the present fire though many articles were burned, spoiled or lost I cannot claim anything because the building alone was insured.

I leave the matter to your consideration with the hope that you will see your way clear to help us substantially and thereby alleviate the burden so heavy at the present time.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

[Handwritten note: "Thompson, Grouard"]

January 23, 1934.

Dear Bishop Guy:

I have your letter of the 13th instant, enclosing a list of the various supplies which were destroyed at the time of the fire at the St. Bernard's Indian Residential School on the 26th of November, last.

Regarding Your Lordship's request for reimbursement for the loss occasioned, I have to say that, upon consideration of the present state of the Appropriation for Indian Education, it is found possible to allow a grant not exceeding the sum of $2,000 towards the purchase of equipment to replace that destroyed by fire. It is considered that it would be more satisfactory if you would arrange for the purchase and forward itemized accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the cost, to a total net exceeding the above amount.

I have examined the list which you enclosed, enumerating the various articles destroyed and the approximate cost. Regarding the articles mentioned as being in school building No. 1, you may arrange for the purchase of a teacher's desk and three bookcases. An order is being placed here to forward the quantity of blackboard, chalk trough and moulding. It will therefore not be necessary for you to purchase this equipment.

The Department could not pay accounts covering the cost of food supplies to replace those destroyed, as the Auditor would object to an expenditure for this purpose. The only articles which can be authorized on the list which you submitted for the hospital would be the four last items.

With reference to the supplies that were in the laundry, we could not authorize replacement of the empty gasoline barrels, children's sleighs, Sisters' headgear and costumes and fountain pens. Further, it will not be possible to pay the cost of replacing the food supplies in the milkhouse, such as butter, lard, tea, bacon and meat. I would

I would request, further, that Your Lordship will arrange to complete the purchases, have the accounts received and forwarded to the Department in time to make payment before our books close at the end of the present fiscal year, March 31st, next. I am leaving in your hands the purchase of the equipment, to the total amount authorized, as I feel sure Your Lordship will be in a better position to decide the various articles necessary.

I note that it is not the general policy of your Diocese to carry insurance on Indian residential school buildings.

My Dear Doctor McGill:-

Your kind letter of January 23rd was received here during my absence. I take great pleasure in acknowledging same today and thanking you for the grant which you have found possible to allow in favor of St Bernard Indian Residential School. Please transmit to the Honorable the Superintendent General my appreciation and the expression of my gratitude.

I note the different paragraphs of your valuable communication and will act according to instructions given. For that purpose I will take the trip to Edmonton on the list and buy the different articles shown on lists. I must say however that a few items have been brought to my attention since my letter of January 13th as having been lost in the fire but they do not amount to much. I intend to change some articles as for example the laundry equipment. Instead of 8 washing machines (hand) and wringers I may buy two or three power ones with greater capacity, etc. Then, I note that I cannot procure some of the items from the firms on the approved list, e.g., teacher's desks, bookcases, knitting machine, soap and soap flakes. I would suggest that you allow me to buy the school equipment from Moyer's in Edmonton and give me the name of a wholesale grocer or merchant for soaps. If Snowdon Oil Co is on the list I would buy from same. Regarding mattresses I usually buy from Parkhill Bedding Co who is on the approved list (at least in Winnipeg) and who have a warehouse in Edmonton. They have special prices for Indian Residential Schools. If above suggestions and requests are agreeable I would kindly ask you to write to me upon reception of this present letter (Monday the 19th) at 9916-110th Street, Edmonton, where I will be Wednesday night (the 21st) just for the very purpose of making necessary purchases.

Hoping that every thing will be found in order and thanking you again for the practical attention given to my requests, I remain

Yours very truly,

Bishop of Grouard.

Dear Mr. Gonthier,

I have your letter of the 22nd ultimo, regarding cheque No. 39807, for $1,038.50, issued in favour of Gaults Limited, for clothing and other supplies for the St. Bernard's Indian Residential School.

The St. Bernard's Indian Residential School is conducted under the auspices of the Bishop of Grouard. A severe loss by fire was suffered at this school in October, 1932. The buildings were partially rebuilt and refitted following the fire. Another fire occurred in November, 1933, and the Bishop found it impossible to provide funds for refitting the building a second time. He appealed to the Department for assistance and, as the St. Bernard's School provides educational facilities for a large group of Indians, the Department considered it advisable to authorize purchase of the materials covered by the account in question. I might point out that a considerable portion of this account covered the cost of sheeting and blankets, which articles the Department has been in the practice of supplying to new residential schools during the past eight or nine years without any exception being taken. The St. Bernard's School can fairly be considered a new school inasmuch as the building had to be rebuilt after the recent fire.

Yours very truly,

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

Memorandum:

MR. BUSKARD,

Replying to your memo of the 7th instant, regarding any new construction or alterations to buildings at the Indian Residential Schools in the diocese of Grouard, I would say His Lordship Bishop Guy has requested that an appropriation be provided to undertake the following work:

1. ST. BRUNO'S - New Barn (approximate cost) - $1,500.
2. WABASCA - Stable and Barn (approximate cost) - $3,000.
3. FORT VERMILION - To replace building destroyed by fire, there is required a new girls' residence - approx. cost - $15,000.
4. ST. BERNARD'S - (a) To replace five buildings destroyed by fire, there is required a building to include 4 classrooms, laundry, dormitory, living quarters and sewing room for older girls - approximate cost - $12,000.
   (b) Ice house and pantry - $1,500.
   (c) Cow barn - $2,500.
5. STURGEON LAKE - (a) New girls' residence - $15,000.
   (b) Repairs to boys' residence - $5,000.

During my visit, last summer, to the St. Bernard's and Sturgeon Lake Residential Schools, consideration was given to the erection of a new building, centrally located, to replace the present old buildings at these two schools. Bishop Guy, I understand, is considering this suggestion. If, and when, a new building is erected, it should provide accommodation for approximately 175 pupils.

The above requests of His Lordship will receive consideration when our Estimates for the next fiscal year are being prepared. However, I am unable to state what amount will be approved for carrying out the work requested by Bishop Guy at any of the above named schools.

Deputy Superintendent General.
November 22nd, 1934.

Dear Bishop Guy,

Please refer to your telegram to us of September 5th. The Department has been giving serious consideration to your requirements indicated therein, in the preparation of our Estimates for the next fiscal year. I have furnished the Honourable the Superintendent General with a memorandum setting out the details of these requests and those received in connection with your schools at Babineax and Fort Vermilion.

I have lately had an opportunity of discussing this matter at some length with the Honourable the Superintendent General. The Minister does not look with much favour upon the building of new schools at the present time, but is prepared to consider new structures in the way of replacing buildings that have outlived their usefulness. In this connection I placed before the Honourable the Minister the suggestion that I had made to Your Lordship when you were in Ottawa, that is to say the advisability of consolidating your two schools at Grandin and Sturgeon Lake respectively, and building one modern structure to take care of the children not being accommodated in these two schools. The Department would favour a new structure being built at a point more accessible to railway communication, but I should think that the present site of St. Bernard's would not be unacceptable.

The Governor General in Council,-

The undersigned has the honour to report that building operations enumerated hereunder were carried out during the past summer at each of the St. Bernard's, St. Bruno's, Sturgeon Lake and Wabasca Roman Catholic Indian Residential Schools, located in the Lesser Slave Lake Indian Agency, northern Alberta.

As these schools are in an isolated locality, it has been found that the most economical method of arranging for construction is to place the work in charge of the Oblate Order, under whose auspices they are conducted. All work was approved by the Department and carried out on a day labour basis, under the direct supervision of His Lordship Right Reverend Joseph Guy, O.M.I., Bishop of Grouard, at a cost of $24,800. The cost of the work at each school, including material and labour, was as follows:-

ST. BERNARD'S:

Erection of a new building, to provide classrooms, sewing-room, dormitory and laundry - $16,000.

ST. BRUNO'S:

Repairing foundation, main building - $3,300.
Erecting kitchen - $1,400.
Erecting barn - $1,500. 6,200.

STURGEON LAKE:

Miscellaneous repairs, school buildings - $600.

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

Synopsis of Memorandum to Council of November 6th, 1935.

The St. Bernard's, St. Bruno's, Sturgeon Lake and Wabasca Indian Residential Schools, located in the Lesser Slave Lake Indian Agency, northern Alberta, are owned and conducted under the auspices of the Oblate Order. His Lordship Right Reverend Joseph Guy, O.M.I., Bishop of Grouard, requested that assistance be given by the Department towards the cost of certain repairs and the erection of buildings at the above schools. The Department provided the amount required in the Estimates for Indian Education for the fiscal year 1935-36. The work, authorized by the Department, was carried out during the past summer. Owing to the rather isolated location of the schools, it was considered the most economical method was to place the work in charge of the church authorities. Bishop Guy arranged for the purchase of the materials and for the labour and had the work carried out on a day labour basis, under his direct supervision. The total cost was $24,800. A request is now being made to His Excellency in Council for the necessary authority for payment of the cost of the above mentioned work.

Ottawa, December 11, 1935.

Gentlemen:

The enclosed accounts covering lumber supplied for the St. Bernard's Indian Residential School have been forwarded to the Department for payment; and, in view of the manner in which they have been prepared, we are unable to decide whether or not they are correct.

With reference to your account of August 19th, one item reads: "2 (4) 1x6 8 #3 Clear Fir Drop Siding 144." From this entry, the Department infers that you supplied 4 bundles of Clear Fir Drop Siding and that each bundle contained 9 pieces, the measurements of each piece being 1x6x8. This makes a total of 144 feet, which is apparently correct.

However, we infer that the next item means 3 pieces 1x6x10, and you show a total of 60 feet. Apparently this should be 15'. The same applies to the subsequent four items. The total of each of these is apparently four times what it should be.

Regarding your accounts of August 20th and 24th, the first item reads: "28 (4) 1x6 8 #2B Clear Fir Drop Siding 448," which is correct. The Department infers that this means 4 bundles, each containing 28 pieces 1x6x8, or a total of 448 feet, which is correct. However, the subsequent five entries are apparently four times too much in quantity.

Similar mistakes appear in 16 subsequent entries on the account. You will note that we have marked these "2 to 17 inclusive".

I would appreciate your amending the accounts and returning them to the Department as soon as possible for payment.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Gentlemen:

We have today received your cheque No. 34096, in the amount of $3010.30, covering payment on account of four cars of lumber shipped by us for the account of Reverend Bishop Guy, Grouard, Alta., during August, 1935, for which we thank you.

We note you have not included the prepaid freight charges, amounting to $1301.21, on these cars, and consequently, we wired Bishop Guy to this effect today. We note, also, that you are deducting 2% cash discount, $58.10, which we also have advised him we are unable to allow at this date. We would refer you to our various invoices, wherein our terms are stated, and are now enclosing copy of our letter of September 6th, last, addressed to Bishop Guy in this connection.

We might respectfully point out that where discount terms are anticipated, it is customary to make a substantial advance payment on account, thus protecting the discount, and in such cases, there is no objection to final payment being delayed for a reasonable time.

We are now forwarding statement covering the balance due, $2821.61, for your further consideration.

Thanking you, we are,

Yours truly,

CANADIAN WESTERN LUMBER COMPANY, LIMITED.

Gentlemen:

I have your letter of the 15th instant, regarding payment of your account for four cars of lumber and the freight charges on same, shipped last summer to the account of His Lordship Bishop Guy, Grouard, Alberta.

In this connection I have to say that cheques in payment of the freight and one car of lumber will go forward in the course of the next few days. I would point out that there was delay in receiving your accounts from His Lordship. Under present regulations, it was necessary to deduct the 2% discount allowed on the lumber, and you will have to look to His Lordship for payment of the amount deducted from your accounts for discount. We are informing His Lordship accordingly.

Ottawa, January 24, 1936.

Right Reverend Sir:

I have Your Lordship's letter of the 16th instant, addressed to Mr. Sutherland, of this Department, concerning payment of accounts of the Canadian Western Lumber Company, covering the cost of the lumber, including freight charges, supplied on your order for use at the Indian residential schools under your auspices.

Cheques in payment for the lumber and freight are being sent to the above company. Under present accounting regulations, it was necessary to deduct the 2% cash discount on the bills covering the cost of the lumber. The company have protested the deduction of the discount, which amounts to approximately $72.56, on the materials supplied. We are unable to pay the company this discount and are informing them that it will be necessary for them to take up the matter with you.

The accounts which you forwarded, covering the cost of the material and labour, erecting the kitchen at the St. Bruno's Indian Residential School, and also the accounts for the labour and wages paid in erecting the classrooms, barns, etc., at the St. Bernard's Indian Residential School were received today, and cheques to reimburse you will be forwarded as soon as these accounts can be passed for payment. There will be sufficient funds in our Appropriation for the current fiscal year to pay the cost for the erection of the kitchen at the St. Bruno's School.

I have the honour to be, Right Reverend Sir,

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

The Department is in receipt of Your Lordship's letter of the 10th ultimo, enclosing labour returns for work at St. Bernard's Indian Residential School. The Representative of the Treasury has found it necessary to make the following changes:

This paylist should include only the name of Alex. Chalifoux and should be receipted by him.

2. Paylist of August 31, 1935 - On this paylist, the name of R. Portlance is shown. Payment is requested for him for 71 hours at 30¢ an hour. The total amount due him would therefore be $21.30. On the paylist which you submitted, you entered $28.40. A deduction of $7.10 has therefore been made.

Ottawa, March 24, 1936.

Dear Mr. Pelletier,

I have received your letter of the 17th instant relating to certain building work carried on by the Roman Catholic Mission at Gaudet, Alberta, during the year 1935, and asking to be advised the wages applicable to labourers and carpenters at that point.

In reply I may state that we have no knowledge in the Department of Labour of the wage rates which are paid to the classifications mentioned in that particular locality. On federal Government building construction work, for which the Department of Labour prepares wage schedules, the minimum rate at the smallest point in the Province of Alberta is 85 cents for labourers and 70 cents for carpenters for a maximum 8-hour day. The work to which you refer, however, was not, insofar as I am aware, a federal Government contract.

If, as suggested, the federal Government contributed financially to this work it would undoubtedly have been through the Department of Indian Affairs, and I am therefore transmitting a copy of your communication to that Department in order that your enquiry on this point may be answered.

Yours sincerely,

R. A. Pelletier, Esq., M.P.,

Honourable and Dear Sir:

An item of $800.00 is included in the Estimates presently under consideration of the House, for school equipment at St. Bernard's Indian Residential School, Grouard, Alta. April 2, 1936.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

I have the memorandum of Mr. Jackson, Private Secretary, of the 27th ultimo, with attached letter from His Lordship Bishop Guy, Grande Prairie, Alberta, requesting payment of an account for the supplying of batteries for the lighting system at the Groizard (St. Bernard's) Indian Residential School and also requesting payment of certain other accounts for materials and labour in the erection of new buildings and alterations and repairs.

In this connection might I say that provision was made in the Appropriation for the fiscal year just closed, to the amount of $24,000, towards the cost of building operations carried out by His Lordship during the past summer at four of the Indian Residential Schools conducted under his auspices, viz.: Groizard (St. Bernard's); Joussard (St. Bruno's); Sturgeon Lake and Wabasca Indian Residential Schools, located in the Lesser Slave Lake Indian Agency, northern Alberta. All work was approved by the Department and carried out on a day labour basis, under the direction of Bishop Guy. The amount available for each school and the work carried out was as follows:

GROIZARD (St. Bernard's)

Erection of a new building, to provide classrooms, sewing-room, dormitory and laundry - $16,000.

JOUSSARD (St. Bruno's)

Repairing foundation, main building - 3,300.
Erecting kitchen - 1,400.
Erecting barn - 1,500. - 6,200.

STURGEON LAKE

Miscellaneous repairs, school buildings - 500.

WABASCA

Erecting machine shed and chicken house - 2,100.

Expenditure of the above amounts was approved by P.C. 3614, dated November 28, 1936. Properly certified accounts were supplied by Bishop Guy, for material and labour, and paid.
and paid, to the amount authorized.

His Lordship, during a recent visit to the Department, was informed that payment could only be made to the amount authorized by the Council in Council. He, however, now submits further accounts which he asks be paid, to the amount of $8,590.62—which include payment for the batteries and for materials and labour in connection with the above mentioned work.

Before he undertook the work last summer, he was definitely informed of the amount that would be available. He however, had some work carried out than was first planned. There is no doubt that the entire work was well done—a part of it having been carried out under the supervision of the Supervisor of Construction appointed by the Department. I would point out that Bishop Guy undertook the extra work at his schools and purchased the batteries without reference to the Department.

There are many instances where the Department has been requested to assume financial responsibility towards the cost of additions, repairs, and maintenance, and for the purchase of equipment and furnishings, at schools which are not government-owned. The policy of the Department in this connection was drawn to the attention of church officials in a memorandum dated April 19, 1934—a copy of which is attached.

The Appropriation for the fiscal year 1935-36 is practically assigned and no provision has been made in our Estimates for the fiscal year 1936-37 to pay the accounts as submitted by Bishop Guy. It is considered that the Department has dealt generously when it has already paid accounts to the amount of $24,800 for improvements at his schools, which are not government-owned properties. I beg to suggest he be informed there are no funds available to pay the accounts which he now submits.

With reference to the question raised by Bishop Guy, regarding discrimination as between government-owned schools and schools which are the property of the church authorities, in the matter of payment for repairs, equipment, etc., I would say that this will form the subject of a separate memorandum.

I return Bishop Guy's letter.

Deputy Superintendent General.

   Three phase, 110 volts — 220 volts, 50 cycles — 60 cycles.

Motor

Shall be American design, of ample capacity and proper speed to insure quiet running, guaranteed to meet operating characteristic of machines and shall be mounted on one of the machines, driving same by belt to overhead shaft. Both direct and alternating current motors shall be horizontal type and insulated to withstand heat and dampness incidental to laundry machinery.

(a) Direct Current
   Shall be furnished with grid covers as protection to commutator and brush rigging.

(b) Alternating Current
   Shall be squirrel-cage, constant-speed type.

Starting Device

Direct Current — Shall consist of an enclosed automatic starter with switch and fuses. A two-button, push-button station shall be furnished for starting and stopping.

Alternating Current — Shall consist of an enclosed automatic starter. A two-button, push-button station shall be provided for starting and stopping.

Wiring

Shall be furnished in conduit between motor and starting device. Proper terminals for line connection shall be left at starting device.
The Canadian Drytex Tumbler

Motor Drive — Non-Reversing Laundry Type

The American Drytex Tumbler quoted shall be (steam, gas, electric), heated, motor driven, belt driven, with a cylinder thirty-six (36) inches in diameter by ... inches in length and shall have ... vertical partitions and ... compartments. Cylinder ribs shall be furnished (with) without padding.

Cylinder — Shall be constructed of 31 - mesh, 100-inch galvanized woven wire, rolled after being woven so that the intersections form interlocked. Cylinder heads shall be of spun galvanized steel, fitted to galvanized steel transmitters. Galvanized-steel bars located between the woven wire to the cylinder heads, to which they shall be securely riveted. Four-inch metal ribs four inches in height shall be riveted to the woven wire and cylinder heads.

The galvanized steel cylinder door shall be of the hinged type, with perforations. Door shall have two latches. A galvanized-steel rib shall be riveted and soldered to the floor sheet between the latches. A hook shall be provided to hold the cylinder door in the open position.

Frame — The upper sections of both side frames shall be of cast-iron, lined with galvanized steel sheets, and bolted together at the horizontal center line of the cylinder. The lower sections shall be bolted to the frame stand, which shall consist of heavy steel angles securely welded. The angles shall form the supports for the fan bearings and driving mechanism. The upper frame sections shall support the housing for the heating units.

Housing — The outer shell or housing shall be constructed of galvanized steel, rigidly attached to the upper and lower side sections. Shall be of close fitting construction, to prevent leakage of air and heat. Housing shall be fitted with a sliding galvanized steel door.

Steam Heating Unit — The heating unit designed to operate on 100 pounds steam pressure shall be located in a galvanized-steel housing at the upper rear of the tumbler. The heater unit shall be of the fin type and of ample capacity to insure proper heating of the tumbler. The air entering the heater housing through the screened cover shall be heated while passing between the fins and over the pipes of the heating unit, and shall then be drawn through the cylinder by means of a fan located below the cylinder.

Gas Heating Unit — The heating unit shall be located in a galvanized-steel housing at the upper rear of the tumbler. The heating unit gas jets shall consist of two 2-inch pipes extending the entire length of the housing. These pipes shall be plugged at one end and fitted with two rows of 1/2-inch nipples one inch long, and be mounted about 1/2 inches apart the entire length of the two pipes.

At the open end of each 2-inch pipe shall be attached a gas and air mixing chamber for the purpose of obtaining the proper gas and air mixture. A large gas valve shall be connected to these mixing chambers for regulating the gas to be consumed.
The Canadian Drytex Tumbler—Continued

Motor Drive—Belt Drive—Non-Reversing Laundry Type

A pilot light shall extend from the main gas line to the burning chamber. Located within the housing or burning chamber shall be a sheet metal baffled plate with a ring around it so that air shall enter the housing through the screened top and shall pass between the baffles and fans and be heated before being drawn through the cylinder by the fans. The baffles shall also prevent the dust from passing over the open gas ring. The heating unit shall be adjustable for various degrees of heat and shall be of ample capacity to insure proper heating of the tumbler.

Electric Heating Unit.—The heating unit shall be located in a galvanized steel housing at the upper rear of the tumbler. It shall consist of a framework in which shall be incorporated electric heaters of proper capacity, arranged so that maximum heating value is obtained.

The heating unit shall be self-contained and easily removable. The air shall enter through the screened top of the housing, shall be heated while passing over the heating elements and shall then be drawn through the clothes by means of fans located below the cylinders.

The heating unit shall be energized through a magnetic switch which shall be activated by the closing of the shell door and interlocked so that the fan must be running while the heaters are in circuit. Opening the shell door shall de-energize the heaters.

Fans.—There shall be one fan assembly on the 36 x 36 inch machine, and two on the 36 x 48 inch machine. Each fan unit shall consist of two cast aluminum paddle-wheel type fans, placed back to back in a galvanized steel housing. Galvanized steel chutes shall be attached to each side of the casing, and to the front bottom shelf sheet. Each fan assembly shall be 12 inches high and 7½ inches wide, and mounted on a through shaft mounted in self-aligning ball bearings, and shall be "V" belt driven.

Bearings.—The cylinder and fan bearings shall be of the self-aligning ball-bearing type. The intermediate bearing shall be plain.

Brake—Motor Drive.—Should be of the manually operated type, located on the left hand end of the tumbler. The braking mechanism and the outer case door shall be interlocked with a switch in such a manner that all electrical circuits shall be automatically broken and the brake shall be applied when the outer case door is opened.

The motor shall be controlled by a fused knife-switch mounted on the back of the machine and connected through a rocker arm lever. The brake shall be held fully engaged at all times. When the brake is applied the brake shoe shall be brought into contact with the gear of the cylinder sheave by action of the rocker arm brake shoe lever. The brake shall be interlocked with the tub door, preventing the brake from being applied when the tub door is closed. Opening the shell door shall break the motor circuit, apply the brake, and stop the fan and cylinder. The brake lever shall also be used for spotting the cylinder.

Brake—Belt Drive.—A manually operated brake shall be located on the left hand end of the tumbler. The brake handle and outer case door shall be interlocked so that opening the case door shall engage the clutching of the drive belt from the tight pulley to the loose pulley when the case door is opened or the brake moved to the "on" position.

When the brake is applied the brake shoe shall be brought into contact with the cylinder sheave by action of a counterweight lever. The brake lever shall not be applied when the tub door is closed. Opening the tub door shall shift the drive belt from the tight to the loose pulley and shall apply the brake and stop the machine. The brake lever shall also be used for spotting the cylinder.

Guards.—The cylinder and fan driving mechanism and "V" belts shall be enclosed in sheet metal guards to comply with safety codes.

Drive-Motor.—A single motor shall be mounted on a bracket which shall be bolted to the rear framework at the left hand end of the machine. A compound sheave on the motor shaft shall drive the fan and cylinder. A sheave wheel located on the left hand end of the fan shaft shall be connected to the compound motor sheave by a single "V" belt. A single "V" belt from the compound motor sheave shall drive the intermediate compound sheave wheel mounted on a belt tightening bracket on the left hand frame. This intermediate wheel shall be driven by a single "V" belt from the small sheave wheel of the intermediate compound sheave wheel. Both the fan "V" belt and the "V" belt from the motor to the intermediate sheave shall be adjusted by moving the motor on the motor bracket.

Drive-Belt.—A jack-shaft support bracket shall be fastened to the left hand steel angle frame at the rear of the machine. The jack-shaft shall be provided with a tight and loose pulley. A sheave on the jack-shaft shall drive the fan sheave through a simple belt. The jack-shaft shall also be provided with a sheave to drive the intermediate compound sheave bracket and upright support arms for the jack-shaft shall be adjustable for "V" belt take-up.

Electrical Equipment.—The electrical equipment shall conform to applicable sections of standards of the National Electric Manufacturers' Association.

All wiring between electrical units mounted on the machine shall be furnished installed in accordance with the National Electrical Code.

Motor.—A single motor shall be furnished for driving both the cylinder and fan. The motor shall be ball-bearing, grease-lubricated type, of ample capacity and such characteristics to operate the tumbler under continuous, full load operating conditions, without motor temperature rise exceeding 10° C. rise above 10° C. ambient temperature.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of March 9th from Edmonton enclosing your original letter dated February 25th from Ottawa. I was in Edmonton this week and endeavored to get in touch with you but found you had left for Grouard on Monday.

As per your request I am giving you attached particulars of the machines on which you have requested prices etc. In a number of Indian schools in Western Canada, we have installed what we call the Group Laundry equipment which consists of a washer, extractor and single roll ironer, all in one unit and driven from one large motor mounted at the rear of the washing machine. All the machines can be running at once off this motor or each can be run separately. That is to say the washer can be running by itself with the other two machines closed down or the washer and extractor together or all three at the same time. The unit comes exactly as shown on the attached illustration which we have marked No. 1. This would work out considerably cheaper for you than by having each of these machines with its own individual motor. We are, therefore, giving you a proposition showing this Unit together with the Drytex Tumbler which could be placed anywhere on account of it having its own motor and the two sets of laundry tubs and boiler. Then on another proposal we have outlined the prices of the washers, extractor, ironer and Drytex Tumbler each with their own individual motor equipment attached, and the illustrations with this second proposal will give you full details as to the construction of each machine.

In connection with the washers, you have asked for an alternative in a metal washer and the only metal washer which we can quote you would be our CHAMPION CASCADE which is constructed of sheet monel metal in the tub and cylinder, and of course
is a very substantially built piece of equipment. The illustration gives you the specifications of same but the picture shown is of a larger machine than that which we have quoted. The one in our proposal would have only one compartment instead of two as shown in the picture, and the size of it, you will note, is smaller than that mentioned in your letter being a 36" x 36" machine, which has a capacity load of 85 lbs. dry weight, but a 36 x 36" Monel Metal Machine will turn out the work much faster than a machine constructed of wood. Therefore, the 15 lb. less capacity per load than the wood machine would be offset by the shortening of the washing time. The other washer which we have quoted on is the regular CANADIAN GLOBE machine, with which you are familiar, having an inner cylinder of 36 x 54" and a capacity of 100 lbs. dry weight per load.

With reference to the Extractor, you will note that we are now making this with the inner basket having its side sheets constructed of Monel Metal, which is a considerable improvement over the old basket construction. We also have a patented Automatic Oiling Device on the extractor which is an exclusive feature on our machine.

In connection with the #1 HANDY IRONER, we want you particularly to notice that this machine is equipped with an Automatic Safety feed Guard and Pressure Device which is a very important feature. Any movement of the Guard by the person operating the machine, causes the Ironer to stop therefore being a protection against the possibility of getting a finger caught. You will note that this Ironer has quite a large roll when padded, i.e., 13/2" in diameter, which assures a good ironing surface as the roll operates in a concave chest of proper size.

The DRYTEX TUMBLER is of very recent design and has been found to be an efficient and up-to-date method of drying the various pieces that come from the Extractor. This machine is made in two types, i.e., with Non-Reversing Cylinder which means that the inner cylinder only turns one way while the machine is running. Then if desired we build this machine with a cylinder which is of the reversing type which means that it turns an equal number of revolutions each way while the machine is running. You will notice that there is $100.00 difference in the price of the two designs.

You will note we have figured all these prices f.o.b. factory, Toronto, including the Sales Tax, and we have given in each case the weight and approximate freight to Grouard. This is simply for your guidance in arriving at your approximate cost laid down at Grouard, as we presume that you will
wish to buy the machinery on an F.O.B. factory basis,
which is the usual procedure.

I trust that the information which we are sending you will be all that you desire, and wish to apologize for the delay in sending same forward to you. The writer only got back from Edmonton this morning.

Yours very truly,

"We have just received a request to quote on laundry machinery for the Indian School at Grouard, Alberta. Copy of the specifications is enclosed.

You will note that our equipment has been specified, but of course the Government will accept competitive equipment, although I might tell you that it does not have the features which our equipment has, so I presume it boils down to a question of price.

One thing I thought I might write you about is in connection with the Extractor - the second item. We have some reconditioned Extractors in Winnipeg, which could be individually motor driven, and could possibly save the Department $150.00 to $200.00 on such a machine. I am wondering if it is the Department's policy to consider reconditioned equipment. An Extractor, for instance, is a machine which has a life of 25 to 30 years, as there are not many parts to give any trouble. We sell a good many to commercial laundries and hospitals who do not insist on new machinery. I know that you are trying to save money for the Government and would be obliged if you would advise if the Department would consider a reconditioned Extractor.

We will be quoting on this equipment in a few days; in fact the quotations close on June 26th, but I have had to write our Calgary Manager for a little more information."

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

I wish to refer to my memorandum of April third, last, and memoranda from Mr. Jackson, Private Secretary of the 23rd and 29th ultimo, regarding the quotations for the supplying of laundry machinery for the Grouard (St. Bernard's) Indian Residential School, in the Lesser Slave Lake agency, northern Alberta. Quotations have been received as follows:

Stanley Brock, Limited, Winnipeg - $4,134.45
Beaver Soap & Chemicals, Ltd., Winnipeg - $4,104.00

These prices are f.o.b. Jeussard, Alberta, the nearest shipping point to the school, and I attach the quotations, as requested.

The quotation obtained by His Lordship Bishop Guy, from Stanley Brock, Limited, Calgary, Alta., was for the supplying of Group Laundry Equipment, operated in one unit, by one large motor, while the prices from the other two firms are for individual motors for each of the machines. In installing Group Equipment, it would be necessary to have a drive shaft, with pulleys and belting, and it has been found, in schools where this equipment is in use, that there is danger in the persons operating the machine catching their hands or clothing in the belting.

Regarding Mr. Jackson's memorandum of the 23rd ultimo, with extract of a letter received from Stanley

[Handwritten note]

Brock Limited
Brock, Limited, dated Winnipeg, June 19th, last, stating that they could supply a re-conditioned extractor, at a saving of $150 to $200 on their quotation, I would say that it would be more satisfactory to supply entirely new equipment to this outlying school. We have had considerable trouble at our schools, in using re-conditioned laundry equipment, and it is often difficult to obtain new parts. In discussing this matter with the Architect of the Department, he stated that little could be gained in supplying re-conditioned equipment, as there is no guarantee as to the length of service and owing to the difficulty in obtaining and replacing parts that might be required from time to time.

I might add that, while only the sum of $8,500 was provided for this purpose, yet, there are other funds available, which were intended for barn and classroom equipment at this school. Classroom equipment has been obtained and there is a saving of $275.00 in the amount for this purpose. The balance required could be taken from the amount provided for barn equipment.

I would recommend that new laundry equipment, as described in the quotations herewith, be supplied, and I submit same for your consideration. I should be pleased to be advised of the name of the firm with whom the order should be placed.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Motor Drive—Belt Drive—Non-Reversing Laundry Type

The American Drytex Tumbler quoted shall be (steam, gas, electric), heated, (motor driven), (belt driven), with a cylinder thirty-six (36) inches in diameter by ... inches in length and shall have ... vertical partitions, and ... compartments. Cylinder ribs shall be furnished with/without padding.

Cylinder—Shall be constructed of 31⁄2 mesh, .080 inch galvanized woven wire, rolled after being woven so that the intersections are interlocked. Cylinder heads shall be of spun galvanized steel, fitted in galvanized steel transmitter, galvanized steel hoops to hold the woven wire to the cylinder heads, to which they shall be securely riveted. Four-inch metal edge caps shall be riveted to the woven wire and cylinder heads.

The galvanized steel cylinder door shall be of the hinged type, with perforations. Door shall have two latches. A galvanized steel reinforcing rib shall be riveted and soldered to the door sheet between the latches. A hook shall be provided to hold the cylinder door in the open position.

Frame—The upper sections of both end frames shall be of cast-iron, lined with galvanized steel sheets, and bolted together at the lower center line of the cylinder. The lower sections shall be bolted to the frame stand, which shall consist of heavy steel angles secured to the floor. The angles shall form the supports for the fan bearings and driving mechanism. The upper frame sections shall support the housing for the heating units.

Housing—The outer shell or housing shall be constructed of galvanized steel, rigidly attached to the upper and lower frame sections. Shall be of close fitting construction, to prevent leakage of air and heat. Housing shall be fitted with a sliding galvanized steel door.

Steam Heating Unit—The heating unit designed to operate on 100 pounds steam pressure shall be located in a galvanized steel housing at the upper rear of the tumbler. The heater unit shall be of the fin type and of ample capacity to insure proper heating of the cylinder. The air entering the heater housing through the screened coil shall be heated while passing between the fins and over the pipes of the heating unit, and shall then be drawn through the cylinder by means of a fan located below the cylinder.

Gas Heating Unit—The heating unit shall be located in a galvanized steel housing at the upper rear of the tumbler. The heating unit gas jets shall consist of two 2-inch pipes extending the entire length of the housing. These pipes shall be connected to the heater unit by two rows of 1⁄4-inch nipples one inch long, and be mounted about 11⁄2 inches apart the entire length of the two pipes.

At the open end of each 2-inch pipe shall be attached a gas and air mixing chamber for the purpose of obtaining the proper gas and air mixture. A large gas valve shall be connected to these mixing chambers for regulating the gas to be consumed.

Motor Drive—Belt Drive—Non-Reversing Laundry Type

A white light shall extend from the main gas line to the burning chamber. Located within the housing or burning chamber shall be a perforated baffle plate fitted with a number of small fins. The air shall enter the housing through the screened top and shall pass between the baffle plate fins and be heated before being drawn through the cylinder by the fans. The baffle plate shall also cut out the air from passing over the open gas flame. The gas burners shall be adjustable for various degrees of heat and shall be of ample capacity to insure proper heating of the tumbler.

Electric Heating Unit—The heating unit shall be located in a galvanized steel housing at the upper rear of the tumbler. The unit shall consist of a framework in which shall be incorporated electric heaters of proper capacity, arranged so that maximum heating value is obtained.

The heating unit shall be self-contained and easily removable. The air shall enter through the screened top of the housing, shall be heated while passing over the heating elements and shall then be drawn through the clothes by means of fans located below the cylinder.

The heaters shall be energized through a magnetic switch which shall be activated by the closing of the shelf door and interlocked so that the fan must be running while the heaters are in circuit. Opening the shelf door shall de-energize the heaters.

Fans—There shall be one fan assembly, on the 36 x 36 inch machine, and two on the 36 x 48 inch machine. Each fan unit shall consist of two cast aluminum paddle-wheel type fans, placed face to back in a galvanized steel housing. Galvanized steel chains shall be attached to each side of the casing, and to the front bearing cover sheet. Each fan assembly shall be 12 inches in diameter and 7½ inches wide, and mounted on a through shaft mounted in self-aligning ball bearings, and shall be V-belt driven.

Bearings—The cylinder and fan bearings shall be of the self-aligning ball-bearing type. The intermediate bearing shall be plain.

Brake Motor Drive—Shall be of the manually operated type, located on the left hand end of the tumbler. The braking mechanism and the outer case door shall be interlocked with a safety device such that all electrical circuits shall be automatically broken and the brake shall be applied when the outer case door is opened.

The brake shall be controlled by a fused knife-switch mounted on the back of the machine and connected through a race to the brake lever. The brake lever and fan force gear together at all times. When the brake is applied the brake shoe shall be brought into contact with the gear of the force gear by action of the counterweight brake shoe lever. The brake shall be interlocked with the tub door, preventing the brake from being applied when the tub door is closed. The brake lever shall break the motor circuit, apply the brake, and stop the fan and cylinder. The brake lever shall also be used for spotting the cylinder.

Brake Belt Drive—A manually operated brake shall be located on the left hand end of the tumbler. The brake handle and outer case door shall be interlocked so that opening the case door will insure the shifting of the drive belt from the tight pulley to the loose pulley when the case door is opened or the brake moved to the "on" (stop) position.

When the brake is applied the brake shoe shall be brought into contact with the cylinder sheave by action of a counterweight brake shoe lever. The brake shall not be applied when the tub door is closed. Opening the tub door shall shift the drive belt from the tight to the loose pulley and shall apply the brake and stop the machine. The brake lever shall also be used for spotting the cylinder.

Guards—The cylinder and fan driving mechanism and V belts shall be enclosed in sheet metal guards to comply with safety codes.

Drive-Motor—A single motor shall be mounted on a bracket which shall be bolted to the rear framework at the left hand end of the machine. A compound sheave on the motor shaft shall drive the fan and cylinder. A sheave wheel located on the left hand side of the fan shaft shall be connected to the compound motor sheave by means of a V single "V" belt from the compound motor sheave shall drive the intermediate compound sheave wheel mounted on a bell tightening bracket on the left hand frame. The alignment of the sheave wheel driven by a single "V" belt from the small sheave wheel of the intermediate compound sheave wheel. Both the fan "V" belt and the "V" belt from the motor to the intermediate sheave shall be adjusted by moving the arm on the motor bracket.

Drive-Belt—A jack-shaft support bracket shall be fastened to the left hand steel angle frame at the rear of the machine. The jack-shaft shall be connected to the intermediate and loose pulley. A sheave on the jack-shaft shall drive the fan sheave through a single "V" belt. The jack-shaft shall also be provided with a sheave to drive the intermediate compound sheave bracket and upright support arms for the jack-shaft shall be adjustable for "V" belt take up.

Electrical Equipment—The electrical equipment shall conform to applicable sections of standards of the National Electric Manufacturers' Association.

All wiring between electrical units mounted on the machine shall be furnished installed in accordance with the National Electrical Code.

Motor—A single motor shall be furnished for driving both the cylinder and fan. The motor shall be ball-bearing, grease-lubricated type, of ample capacity and such characteristics to operate the tumbler under continuous, full load operating conditions, without motor temperature rise exceeding 10°C rise above 10°C ambient temperature.
