The Honourable the Superintendent General,

I wish to refer to my memorandum of April third, last, and memoranda from Mr. Jackson, Private Secretary, of the 23rd and 28th ultimo, regarding the quotations for the supplying of laundry machinery for the Crocard (St. Bernard's) Indian Residential School, in the Lesser Slave Lake agency, northern Alberta. Quotations have been received as follows:

Stanley Brock, Limited, Winnipeg - $4,184.45
Denver Soap & Chemicals, Ltd., Winnipeg - 4,104.00

These prices are f. o. b. Jeussard, Alberta, the nearest shipping point to the school, and I attach the quotations, as requested.

The quotation obtained by His Lordship Bishop Guy, from Stanley Brock, Limited, Calgary, Alta., was for the supplying of Group Laundry Equipment, operated in one unit, by one large motor, while the prices from the other two firms are for individual motors for each of the machines. In installing Group Equipment, it would be necessary to have a drive shaft, with pulleys and belting, and it has been found, in schools where this equipment is in use, that there is danger in the persons operating the machine catching their hands or clothing in the belting.

Regarding Mr. Jackson's memorandum of the 23rd ultimo, with extract of a letter received from Stanley

- Brock Limited
Brook, Limited, dated Winnipeg, June 18th, last, stating that they could supply a re-conditioned extractor, at a saving of $150 to $200 on their quotation, I would say that it would be more satisfactory to supply entirely new equipment to this outlying school. We have had considerable trouble at our schools in using re-conditioned laundry equipment, and it is often difficult to obtain new parts. In discussing this matter with the Architect of the Department, he stated that little could be gained in supplying re-conditioned equipment, as there is no guarantee as to the length of service and owing to the difficulty in obtaining and replacing parts that might be required from time to time.

I might add that, while only the sum of $3,500 was provided for this purpose, yet, there are other funds available, which were intended for barn and classroom equipment at this school. Classroom equipment has been obtained and there is a saving of $275.00 in the amount for this purpose. The balance required could be taken from the amount provided for barn equipment.

I would recommend that new laundry equipment, as described in the quotations herewith, be supplied, and I submit same for your consideration. I should be pleased to be advised of the name of the firm with whom the order should be placed.

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Mr Sutherland:

I beg to acknowledge letter signed by the Secretary in date of the 13th inst re Laundry Equipment for Grouard Residential School. My night letter of today in the matter is now being explained.

I had given quotations from the Calgary Office of the Stanley Brock Limited. I note by your letter that shipment is made through Winnipeg Branch. May I suggest that credit be given to the Calgary Manager?

I note the omission of the Ironer as included in first quotation and also the elimination of the CANADIAN GROUP DRIVE of three machines viz: Washer, Extractor and Ironer, substituting individual motor driving. May I say that individual motor driving brings up the expense for each machine as you can find out in above mentioned quotations from Calgary. The total figures of the said quotations amounted to $3,210.00 plus approximately $458.00 freight making a total of $3,668.00. In a previous letter I told you that I have secured special rates on the Railway and could have said $458.00 cut to $229.00 making a total of $3,439.00 which would be within the $3,500.00 voted. Why not give me the opportunity of profiting by the advantages given me instead of depriving me of same by direct purchase?

You have given orders for shipment to Joussard. As there is no platform at the Station you will have to ship said Equipment to GROUARD. I prefer that our truck travel 15 miles to Joussard wharf rather than take the risk of unsafe unloading.

I hope the above remarks will be taken into consideration and acted upon. Kindly advise me in the matter. Mr Orr is conversant with the above and could certainly be of help to reach a decision.

Yours very truly,

Bishop of Grouard.

Reverend Sir:

We were very glad to receive the order recently through Ottawa for the laundry machinery. We note that in placing the order they omitted to give you an Ironer, although in your enquiry to us you specified one of these machines.

It has just occurred to the writer that perhaps the reason the Ironer was left off the order was to keep down the investment in this equipment. I am wondering if you could have the Department purchase a reconditioned #1 Handy flatwork Ironer, 66" wide, similar to the new one we quoted you in our letter of March 14th., our Proposal #2. This would be equipped with its own individual motor to set on the floor beside it. I might tell you that this Ironer has been in a laundry in Winnipeg but has not been operating very long and has just recently been replaced by larger equipment. The machine would be sent to you completely overhauled and in first class running order. As you know there is very little that can ever go wrong with an Ironer because there is no continual strain put on the machine like a Washer or Extractor.

Our Winnipeg House has this Ironer and they tell us that you could purchase it for $500.00 complete with D.C. motor as above mentioned, f.o.b. Winnipeg. If you compare this price with the figure quoted in our Proposal of March 14th., you will find that it is practically half of what a new machine would cost you.

Dear Doctor McGill:

I take the liberty of enclosing the letter just received from the Manager of Stanley Brock in Calgary and which is self explanatory.

A sum of $3,500 has been voted for Laundry Equipment at Grouard and $3,096 is applied to new equipment which is expected here any day. A mangle has been omitted though requested because amount would have been exceeded.

If the Ironer mentioned in Mr Cochrane's letter could be bought by the Department I would pay the difference. I leave the whole matter to your kind appreciation.

Ottawa, September 4, 1936.

Right Reverend Sir:

I have been directed to acknowledge receipt of Your Lordship's letter of the 27th ultimo, enclosing a communication which you received from Stanley Brock, Limited, offering to supply an ironer, complete with motor, which was in operation for a short time in a laundry in Winnipeg, for the sum of $500.00, f. o. b. Winnipeg.

In this connection I would point out that only the sum of $3,500.00 has been provided for laundry equipment, and, as you were informed, an order has been placed to supply this equipment, to the amount of $3,086.65. This would leave a balance of only $403.35 available to purchase the ironer. I might say, further, that an amount of only $2,200.00 was provided to supply barn equipment for the schools at Grouard and Jossard, while accounts covering the cost of this equipment have been paid to the amount of $2,361.74, or $161.74 in excess of the sum provided. I regret, therefore, that the Department will be unable to supply the used ironer offered by Stanley Brock, Limited, during the current fiscal year.

When our Estimates are being prepared for the next fiscal year, consideration will be given to placing an item therein to provide for supplying a new ironer, at a cost of approximately $1,050.00.

Any balance on hand from the amount provided for laundry equipment could be utilized, as suggested by you, in paying for the cost of piping and the work of installing the laundry equipment.

I have the honour to be,

Right Reverend Sir,

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

With reference to enquiry, by phone, from your office yesterday, regarding the equipment, repairs and improvements authorized by Order in Council (P.C. 18/1936) dated July 24, 1936, at each of the Grouard (St. Bernard's), Doussard (St. Bruno's) and Wabasca Roman Catholic Indian Residential Schools, in the Lesser Slave Lake Indian Agency, northern Alberta, I would state as follows:

The Oblate Order own and conduct these schools. Details of the expenditure are set forth in the Order in Council. Right Reverend Joe Guy, C.M.I., Bishop of Grouard, arranged for the purchase of the barn equipment for the two first named schools and also for the work at the Wabasca R.C. School. The classroom equipment for Grouard was ordered through the purchasing branch of this Department. Accounts have been received and paid, covering the cost of the barn, laundry and classroom equipment.

The general repairs at Grouard and the installing of the water pressure tank, etc., at Wabasca are being carried out in charge of the church authorities, and the accounts covering the cost of this work have not yet been received. Dear Doctor McGill:

I have seen the Minister in the matter and have hope from him of serious consideration. He has authorized the preparation of plans which will be ready shortly when Mr Orr will be able to give an approximate price for construction. If the Minister finds he is unable for the present year to supply the whole amount I would certainly consider a substantial account and borrow the balance same to be reimbursed by the Department next year.

May I say that all the schools in my Vicariate have been built at our expense with the exception of Joussand. I therefore consider that after such a trying experience as our last fire I should be substantially helped.

And if I am allowed to express all my mind I will say that after the 25 years of service and cooperation with the Department, during which time I have certainly saved money for the Department and given moral help of every kind, I was under the impression that no hesitation would have existed in the matter of giving a hand. Concrete Aggregates shall be free from alkali, organic material or other deleterious substances and shall not contain soft, friable, thin, flaky, elongated or laminated particles totalling more than 3 per cent or containing shale in excess of 1/4 per cent or silt or crusher dust finer than the No. 100 standard sieve in excess of 2 per cent. These percentages shall be based on the weight of the combined aggregate as used in the concrete. When all three groups of these deleterious materials are present, the combined amounts shall not exceed 5 per cent by weight of the combined aggregate.

Fine and coarse aggregate shall be delivered and stored separately.

Fine aggregate shall range in size from fine to coarse within the following limits:

| Percent by weight |
|-------------------|
| Passing 3/8" sieve - not less than | 100 |
| " #4 sieve - not less than | 90 |
| " #60 sieve - not less than | 8 to 30 |
| Weight removed by decantation - not more than | 3 |

Sand when tested in accordance with the Method of Test for Organic Impurities in Sand in Concrete as specified in Appendix "K" of the Standards Specification for Concrete and Reinforced Concrete (No. A23-1929) of the Canadian Engineering Standards Association, shall show a colour not darker than the standard colour.

Coarse aggregate shall range in size from fine to coarse within the following limits:

| Percent by weight |
|-------------------|
| Passing 3/4" sieve - Not less than | 95 |
| " #4 sieve - Not more than | 10 |
| " #8 sieve - Not more than | 5 |

Coarse aggregate shall consist of screened gravel having clean uncoated particles.

Water for concrete shall be clean and free from injurious amounts of oil, acid, alkali, organic matter or other deleterious substances.

Reinforcing Steel shall conform to the Standard Specification for Reinforcing Materials for Concrete (No.A9-1923) of the Canadian Engineering Standards Association. The material for main reinforcement shall be either Rail steel or hard grade new Billet steel. Stirrups shall be structural grade billet steel.

Storage of Materials

Cement and aggregates shall be stored at the job in a manner to prevent deterioration or the intrusion of foreign matter. Any material which has deteriorated or has been damaged shall be immediately removed from the job.

Reinforcing material shall be stored on racks or skids so it is protected from dirt and will maintain its fabricated form.

Concrete Proportions

Concrete for structural members shall be mixed in the proportion of one (1) part of Portland Cement to 5 parts of combined aggregate, and not more than 5 Imperial gallons of water per sack of cement.

The aggregates shall be measured separately and shall be in the ratio of approximately 4 parts of fine aggregate to approximately 7 parts of coarse aggregate - measured dry.
The total amount of water entering the mix shall not exceed the water-cement ratio given and shall include the surface water carried by the aggregate. When not determined accurately by tests, the amount of surface water shall be assumed as follows:

| Imperial Gallons per cubic foot |
|---------------------------------|
| Fine aggregate - Damp           | 1/3   |
| - Moderately wet                | 1/2   |
| - Wet                           | 3/4   |
| Course aggregate - Wet          | 1/4   |

This mixture shall have a strength in compression at the age of 28 days, as determined by cylinder tests, of at least 2000 pounds per square inch.

Concrete for concrete floor finish shall be mixed in the proportion of one (1) part of Portland cement, to one (1) part of fine aggregate to two (2) parts of pea gravel graded between 1/4" and 3/8" in size, and not over 4½ Imperial gallons of water per sack of cement. Allowance shall be made for surface water carried by aggregate as previously specified.

**Concrete Mixing**

All concrete shall be mixed in a batch mixer of an approved type. The mixer shall be equipped with a water storage tank and a water measuring device which can be set so that the same and correct amount of water is supplied to each batch. Water shall not be admitted to the mixer while it is being discharged.

The mixing of each batch shall continue for not less than one minute after all the materials are in the mixer. The volume of the mixed materials per batch shall not exceed the manufacturer's rated capacity. The mixer during mixing shall revolve at the peripheral speed recommended by the manufacturer.

The retempering of concrete which has partially hardened, that is, remixing with or without additional cement, aggregate, or water, will not be permitted.

**Placing Concrete**

Before placing concrete, all equipment for mixing and transporting the concrete shall be cleaned of hardened concrete and foreign materials. All debris and ice shall be removed from the places to be occupied by the concrete. All forms shall be thoroughly soaked with water (except in freezing weather), or oiled.

Concrete shall be handled from the mixer to the place of final deposit as rapidly as possible, by methods which will prevent the separation or loss of the ingredients. Concrete shall be deposited in the forms, as nearly as practicable, in its final position to avoid reshuffling or flowing. Under no circumstances shall concrete that has partially hardened be deposited in the forms.

When concreting is once started, it shall be carried on as a continuous operation until the pacing of the section is completed.

Concrete shall be thoroughly compacted by puddling with suitable tools during the operation of placing and shall be thoroughly worked around the reinforcement, embedded fixtures, and into the corners of the forms. Special care shall be taken in compacting the concrete in metal forms so as to eliminate all honey combing in the finished surfaces.

**Construction Joints**

Construction joints in columns shall be made at the underside of the floor slab.
Construction Joints (continued)

Construction joints in floors shall be located near the centre of spans of slabs, beams, joists and girders, unless a beam intersects a girder at this point, in which case, the joint in the girder shall be offset a distance equal to twice the width of the beam. In this case, adequate provision shall be made for shear by the use of inclined reinforcement.

At least 2 hours must elapse after depositing concrete in columns or walls before depositing in beams, girders, joists or slabs supported thereon.

The surface of hardened concrete shall be roughened and thoroughly cleaned of foreign matter and laitance and shall be saturated with water and the form retightened against the face of the hardened concrete before depositing additional concrete. An excess of mortar on hardened surfaces shall be secured by thoroughly rodding the freshly deposited concrete to remove the coarse aggregate from contact with the hardened concrete.

Curing

After being placed, all floors shall be covered as soon as possible with a layer, at least one inch thick, of shavings, sawdust or sand, which shall be kept continuously moist for at least 7 days.

Walls and other concrete surfaces shall be kept moist by sprinkling or other methods for at least 4 days.

Cold Weather Requirements

When depositing concrete at freezing or near-freezing temperatures, the concrete shall have a temperature of between 50 degrees Fahr. and 100 degrees Fahr. It shall be maintained at a temperature of at least 50 degrees Fahr. for not less than 4 days after placing. When the surrounding atmosphere has a temperature lower than 40 degrees Fahr., all aggregates and water shall be preheated and all reinforcement, forms fillers and ground with which the concrete is to come in contact, shall be defrosted.

All canvas and other protective coverings shall be kept clear of the concrete to permit free circulation of air around all columns and over the tops of all slabs and beams.

Salts, chemicals and other substances shall not be added to the mixture with a view to the prevention of freezing.

Manure and other injurious substances shall not be allowed to come in contact with fresh concrete.

Reinforcement

Metal reinforcement, before being placed, shall be free from rust, scale or other coatings that will destroy or reduce the bond. Reinforcement shall be formed to the dimensions indicated on the plans. The diameter of bends shall not be less than 8 times the diameter of the bar.

Metal reinforcement shall not be bent or straightened in a manner that will injure the material. Bars, with kinks or bends not shown on the plans, shall not be used. Heating of reinforcement for bending will not be permitted.

Metal reinforcement shall be accurately placed and secured and shall be supported by concrete or metal chairs or spacers, or metal hangers. Brick, wood, gypsum, tile or similar materials shall not be used to support the reinforcement.
FORMS

Forms shall conform to the shape, lines and dimensions of the member called for on the plans. They shall be substantial and sufficiently tight to prevent the leakage of mortar; they shall be properly braced and tied so as to maintain their position and shape. Temporary openings shall be provided where necessary, to facilitate cleaning immediately before depositing concrete. Bolts and rods used for internal ties shall be so arranged that, when the forms are removed, there shall be no metal within one inch of any surface. Wire ties will be permitted on unimportant work; they shall not be used through surfaces where discoloration will be objectionable.

Wood Forms for exposed surfaces shall be built of lumber dressed to a uniform width and thickness and free from loose knots and other defects. Joints in forms shall be horizontal or vertical. For unexposed surfaces, plastered surfaces and rough work, undressed lumber may be used. Lumber once used in forms shall have the nails withdrawn and surfaces to be in contact with concrete thoroughly cleaned before being reused.

Removal of Forms

Forms shall not be disturbed until the concrete has hardened adequately, nor shall the permanent shores be removed until the structure has attained its full design strength and all excess construction loads have been removed. Wall and column forms shall be left in place until the concrete has hardened sufficiently to sustain its own weight and construction loads likely to come upon it. Forms other than wall or column forms shall be left in place until the concrete has hardened sufficiently to carry the full load which it must sustain, unless removed in sections and each section immediately reshored.

Floors

All floors on earth shall be prepared by a thorough compacting of the earth at the level required. Where the excavation has been carried deeper than intended or where pockets of poor soil have been encountered and cleaned out, clean earth, broken brick or stone shall be used for fill and shall be thoroughly tamped so that no later settlement will occur. Unless such extra excavation has been ordered by the architect in writing, there shall be no charge for any fill required.

On the prepared subgrade shall be placed 4 inches of screened cinders which shall be well tamped and kept moist. Any waterpipes, electric conduits or other metal piping which pass through the cinder fill shall be encased in about 3 inches of concrete so that the cinder fill does not come in contact with the metal.

On the cinders shall be placed concrete to the thickness shown on the plans, screeded level to receive the finish as specified later.

Upper floors and roof shall be built to the thickness shown on plans and the concrete shall be screeded level to receive the finish as specified later.

Where floor drains are indicated on the plans, the concrete floor shall be carefully graded to the drains so that there is a true even slope of the amount and in the direction shown on the plans.

Floor Finish

Floors shown on plans as a cement finish shall have the concrete base prepared by being swept, flushed with water and thoroughly scrubbed with stiff brushes. All dirt, mortar and plaster droppings shall be cleaned off the floor. Free water shall be removed but the floors must be kept damp. The floor shall then be painted with a neat cement grout well brushed in. Grouting shall not be done more than 10 minutes before the finish is laid. Any portion grouted longer than this, before the finish is laid, shall be scrubbed off and regouted immediately in advance of the finish course.
Floor Finish (continued)

The finish course shall be not less than one (1) inch thick of concrete of the mixture specified for floor finish. It shall be of the driest consistency possible to work with a sawing motion of the straight edge. This consistency may be varied by the addition or deduction of the coarse aggregate but not less than 1½ parts of coarse aggregate shall be used. The addition of fine aggregates or water to give increased workability will not be permitted.

After placing the concrete, it shall be screeded to the correct grade and compacted with a wooden float, as soon as possible after screeding. Floating shall not be continued longer than is necessary to bring the minimum amount of mortar to the surface for finishing. After the concrete has set sufficiently, it shall be trowelled to a smooth hard, dense and level surface. If necessary, the surface shall receive a second trowelling. Over-trowelling shall be avoided and no drier shall be used.

Finished concrete surfaces

Exposed concrete in walls or ceilings shall be treated as follows; After the forms are removed, cut away all projections and fins and point up all depressions, air holes and other roughnesses with a mortar composed of one part of Portland Cement to two parts of sand, while the concrete is still fresh. Thoroughly wet the surface before pointing. All corners shall be sharp and true. The surface shall then be rubbed with a carborundum brick until the surface has a smooth even texture. No cement or other wash shall be used. (Note: It is not the intention to remove the form marks, but to make them smooth and true).

Memorandum:

Mr. MacInnes,

The Commissioner of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police has referred here a telegram from Bishop Guy reading as follows -

"Would appreciate renting at barracks and house situated Grouard, Alberta and not occupied for many years. Stop I would like to use same to house men presently building for Department Indian Affairs residence for boys at Indian Residential School. Stop Kindly wire me at Grouard."

In this connection I may say that Lot 39, Lesser Slave Lake comprising twenty-one acres was transferred to the Royal Canadian Mounted Police by Order in Council, P.C. 1765, dated the 5th of August, 1930.

In a letter dated the 13th July, 1935, J.W. Spalding, Deputy Commissioner, relinquished the land and it reverted to this Department, and in a further letter dated the 12th August following, relinquished the buildings described as follows -

(1) 1 very substantial log building, 24 x 28 with a 16 x 14 leanto. (Living Quarters). Built in 1930 at a cost of $3,650. Approximate present value .. $2,000.
(2) 1 very old log building 22 x 40 with a 22 x 12 leanto. (Officers quarters). Built in 1913 or 1914; present value $50.

(3) 1 combination stable and garage 14 x 20 suitable for three horses and one car. Built in January, 1931, at a cost of $1,600. Approximate present value, $850.

(4) 1 ice house 10 x 12'. Approximate value $10.

(5) Fencing in 1926, $6.

The property is at present vacant and is reported to be fast deteriorating on that account.

Evidently Bishop Guy wishes to use these buildings to house the men who are to be employed by your Department to build the residence for boys at the Indian residential School. Have you any information about this. Please advise me.

Director.

Dear Sir,

Persuant to our conversation of the other day, I am addressing you enclosed the list of what is needed for the new boys residence at the Grouard Indian School. Dear Mr. McGill,

I wonder if the other day when applying for beds destined to our new residence for boys at Grouard, I have specified the kind of beds we would like to get. I enclose a catalog sheet showing same. We have a nice building; the furniture should suit with.

You will hear soon through Mgr Guy about the Laundry Equipment needed at Grouard. He has kindly accented to help me in this matter. The worst will be to pay for. I understand that an appropriation has been made last year for a part at least of that equipment. Could not the Department carry the balance?... The fire of last winter has brought us so heavy expenses that I foresee to be tied up if I have to put a few thousands dollars on that Laundry Equipment. I imagine that it would be a pleasure and a satisfaction for the Department to complete the splendid work done here. I leave the suggestion to your appreciation.

I had hoped to be in a position to send you a photo of the new building. Unfortunately, it has been cloudy since I am back. I will profit by the first chance to get a good photo.

Best wishes for Christmas and new year.

Believe, Dear Mr. McGill,

Yours very truly,

F. S. Lejol, O.M.I.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Bailey

The boys' wing of the Grouard Residential School, which was destroyed by fire on January 13, 1937, has been rebuilt by the Church authorities and, following our usual practice, I recommend that the articles shown on the attached order form be supplied as soon as possible.

The beds required are known as "institutional beds" and should be Simmons No. 4,000, or equal.

The mattresses should, of course, fit the beds. In 1935 we purchased mattresses from Simmons Limited and, at that time, they gave the following specifications:- "Filling to be white layer linter - cotton felt - furnished with stitched rolled edge - diamond tufting, having 17 cotton tufts - 4½" bags - weight to be not less than 30 pounds".

The sheeting is required both for sheets and pillow cases. We have formerly supplied cotton sheeting for this purpose. The last large supply of this sheeting that we purchased was secured from the Dominion Textile Co. Ltd., Montreal, and was known as their:- "No. 5/4S 22 cotton sheeting (72" wide, strong, unbleached - good quality)". I am not certain how many yards there are in a roll and therefore it might be necessary for you to accept delivery of slightly more than 350 yards. You will note that this sheeting is 72" wide and the sheets and pillow cases can be made up at the school.

When outfitting the Shingwauk Home in 1935, we purchased 160 pillows from Simmons Limited, Montreal. The specifications in connection with these pillows, as quoted by Simmons Limited, were:- "19" by 26", mixed chicken feathers - weight per pair to be not less than six pounds and covered with feather proof art ticking."

As you are aware a brand new Laundry Equipment was destroyed on January 13, 1937 in the fire which razed the Boys' Residence at Grouard. Since the Sisters and children wash clothes in small washing machines. I may say that previous to the installation of the above mentioned equipment which was used only twice they had, after the destruction of the former laundry, three years previous, been obliged to travel thirty miles twice a month in every kind of road and specially by boat in order to wash clothes at Joussard School.

It is impossible to allow such a situation to recur and therefore I have been directed by present Diocese and School authorities to make a formal request for an equipment similar to the previous one. The cost of the latter was $5,100.00 and was perfectly modern and satisfactory in every respect. It consisted of the following Canadian Laundry Machinery Machines (supplied through Stanly Brock of Winnipeg):

1 - 36" x 54" Canadian Globe Woodwasher 110 V.D.C. with individual motor.

1 - 26" Extractor Inner Basket and angle countershaft attached and individual motor.

1 - Canadian Drytex Tumbler with 36" x 48" Inner Cylinder

1 - 10 H.P. Vulcan Horizontal Steam boiler and usual fittings.

Ajax Cement granitine Laundry Tubs (3 compartments)

A No.1 Canadian Handy Flatwork Ironer 66" long roll, steam heated had been provided for in the present year Estimates at a cost of $1,050.00.
May I suggest that the equipment be installed in the Boys' New Residence? If the Department is unable to supply the sum presently a combination could be made with the above $1050.00 and balance on $3,000.00 voted for Laundry Equipment at Wabaska Indian School. I understand the latter institution will not use total sum. I believe that if the Department could guarantee payment of part of the equipment the Diocese authorities could borrow enough to advance balance until next Estimates are prepared.

With best personal regards, I remain,

Very truly yours,

Bishop of Gravelbourg.
Ottawa, January 29, 1938

My dear Bishop Guy:

I have for acknowledgment Your Lordship's letter of January 8th, in which you refer to the reconstruction of the boys' residence at the Grouard Residential School.

It is scarcely necessary to state that I appreciate very fully the prompt action on your part which resulted in the re-opening of the residence on December 1, 1937. It is very gratifying to note, also, that a modern three-storey building of fireproof construction has been erected.

I have given careful consideration to your request for an additional pupilage grant of $500.00, which grant is, in your judgment, necessary to meet the interest and capital instalment payments on the sum of $40,000.00 for a period of twenty years.

May I refer to my letter to you of April 21, 1937, in which the statement is made "that an additional sum be included in the Estimates yearly to provide for an increase in the per capita pupilage grant, namely $2,500.00, until such additional payments reimburse you for your capital outlay and interest thereon". Owing to the increasing costs for relief, hospitalization and other purposes which are making heavy demands upon the funds voted for the Branch, I regret that it will not be possible to increase the amount of the grant now provided for in the Estimates for next year.

Yours sincerely,

J.A.C.

The Right Reverend J. Guy, O.M.I.,

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL:

The undersigned has the honour to report:

That the Grouard, Joussard, Sturgeon Lake, Wabasca Roman Catholic and Vermilion Indian Residential Schools are located in the Lesser Slave Lake Agency in the Province of Alberta;

That these schools are in an isolated locality and it has been found that the most economical method of arranging for the purchase of several articles of equipment and in carrying out repairs is to place the work in charge of the Oblate Order under whose auspices these schools are conducted;

That the total expenditure, during the fiscal year 1937-38, for purchasing of equipment and carrying out repairs at the above-mentioned five schools, all of which are Church owned, was $16,765.94;

That funds to cover the cost of the above-mentioned equipment and labour are available in Vote 169, 1937-38, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources.

The undersigned has the honour to recommend that authority be granted for the expenditure of the said sum of $16,765.94 in payment of the cost of supplying equipment and making repairs at the above-mentioned schools.

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines & Resources.
Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

I enclose memorandum to Council requesting authority to pay accounts amounting to $16,765.94 in connection with the five Indian Residential Schools in the Diocese of Grouard. The above amount is made up as follows:

1. Labour and repairs and improvements to the buildings and purchase of some equipment $12,181.86

Provision for the above amount was specially included in our appropriation for the fiscal year 1937-38 and following the practice of former years His Lordship Right Reverend Jos. Guy, O.M.I., has submitted accounts to the Department covering the above and I am satisfied that we have received good value for the amount expended. A similar Order-in-Council was passed last year (reference my memorandum of March 23, 1937 and P.C. 685 of March 31, 1937).

2. Purchase of beds, mattresses, pillows, cotton sheeting and blankets for the new addition to the Grouard Indian Residential School $1,484.05

In this connection I would refer you to my memorandum to Mr. Bailey of January 10, 1938. The articles mentioned above were purchased through Mr. Bailey's office and their cost is being included in the Order-in-Council.

3. Laundry equipment for Grouard Indian Residential School $3,100.00
This equipment has not yet been purchased but I enclose requisition to the Purchasing Agent. In this connection I would refer you to my memorandum of July 7, 1936. At that time approval was granted for the same articles as are shown on the purchase requisition. The equipment was received in good order at the school but was destroyed by the fire at the time the portion of the school was burned on January 13, 1937. The laundry machinery previously supplied was purchased on your instruction from Stanley Brock Limited, Winnipeg, and as it was very satisfactory while in use I would recommend that similar equipment be purchased at the present time. I may say that laundry equipment is absolutely necessary at this school.

The total of the above-mentioned three items is $16,765.94 and this amount has been included in the memorandum to Council.

I would appreciate if the Honourable the Minister would give the necessary instructions to the Purchasing Agent to purchase the laundry equipment.

Funds for the total expenditure mentioned above are available in our appropriation for the fiscal year ending March 31 and in the event of the Honourable the Minister approving the purchase of the laundry machinery the Purchasing Agent should be requested to make immediate purchase.

Director.

Dear Mr. McGill,

I have the pleasure to let you know that all the dormitory furniture ordered, on your recommendation, by the Department for our new Boys' Residence has been received, namely: beds and springs; pillows; blankets and cotton sheeting as per Department Order No 2668. I am enclosing five certified copies of reception of each item.

The boys have come to tell me that they had expressed themselves their satisfaction to you and to the Department. These boys will surely remember you, Mr. McGill. After having slept on the floor for nearly a year, they can't believe that they have so good and nice beds. It is understood that I share their pleasure and that I join with them to thank you.

I hear through his Excellency Mgr J. Guy, O.M.I., that you have found a very practical way to handle to the Corporation the sum covering interest and instalment we have to pay on the loan we made for the construction. There is no doubt that it will be very satisfactory for all parties concerned.

Once more, Dear Mr. McGill, accept my thanks for your kindness and believe me yours very truly,

F. S. LaJode, O.M.I.
